1 OCTOBER.part4: For I would not, brethren, that ye should be ignorant of this mystery, lest ye should be wise in your own conceits; that blindness in part is happened to Israel, until the fulness of the Gentiles be come in.
1 OCTOBER.part5:
God has chosen Israel "to be a special people unto Himself, above all people that are upon the face of the earth" [Deuteronomy 7:6]. To them "were committed the oracles of God" [Romans 3:2]. In spite of their privilege, they forsook God "the fountain of living waters" [Jeremiah 2:13]. Their disobedience and unbelief led to spiritual blindness and hardening of their hearts.

The mystery Paul wrote about in verse 25 was the Gospel reaching the Gentiles. The Old Testament had made it clear that Gentiles would be part of God's salvation plan [Genesis 12:1-3; Psalm 117:1; Isaiah 60:3]. But Jews could not accept that "the Gentiles should be fellowheirs, and of the same body, and partakers of his promise in Christ by the gospel" [Ephesians 3:6]. And by their rejecting the Gospel, they also rejected the Christ of the Gospel. They became wise in their own conceit and spiritual blindness set in.

The Jews were zealous, "but not according to knowledge" [Romans 10:2]. Having rejected God's righteousness, they set out to establish their own [Romans 10:3]. Their ignorance and defiance of God would lead to their destruction [Hosea 4:6].

This same danger faces the church today. There are people who sit under the faithful preaching of the Gospel; they hear God's Word taught week after week, but the Word has no lasting effect on them. God's Word to them is like a passing wind, leaving nothing but a tickling of the ears. If we are not careful, our own arrogance and defiance can also cause us to reject God and His Word, and the end result will be a hardening of our hearts to the things of God.
1 OCTOBER.part7: Our hearts under the ministry of God's word can be like a piece of ice that melts under the sun, or like cement that hardens in its heat.

2 OCTOBER.part4: For I would not, brethren, that ye should be ignorant of this mystery, lest ye should be wise in your own conceits; that blindness in part is happened to Israel, until the fulness of the Gentiles be come in.
2 OCTOBER.part5:
The Bible warns against being wise in (our) own conceits" [Romans 12:16]. This is the cause of spiritual blindness - an ailment that afflicted the children of Israel. In their attempt to keep out Gentiles from God's redemptive plan, they kept themselves from the Promised Messiah.

Paul writes that this "blindness in part is happened to Israel". To be sure, the blindness which fell on the Jews was not arbitrary but the result of God's righteous judgment against their willful ignorance of the truth and defiance against Him.

There are two ways to look at this "partial" blindness. The first view is that this blindness of the Jews resulting from their rejection of Christ will be lifted at some future time, and they will finally embrace Jesus and the truth of the Gospel. In other words, this judicial blindness would end when Christ returns. The other view takes it that only a portion of Jews were stricken with this blindness. After all, Paul and the other apostles were Jews, as were many of the early believers in the first-century church.

Regardless of how one views this "partial blindness", there is embedded in it the grace of God - grace that is applied both to Jews and Gentiles. Grace to the Gentiles because the Gospel of Christ never excluded believing Gentiles. Grace to the Jews because this blindness is partial and believing Jews would also be brought back into the fold of salvation. All - Jew and Gentile alike - stand equally in need of a Saviour. All are one in Christ.
2 OCTOBER.part7: The gospel of Christ .. is the power of God unto salvation to every one that believeth; to the Jew first, and also to the Greek. - Romans 1:16.

3 OCTOBER.part2: Fullness of Gentiles Be Come In
3 OCTOBER.part4: For I would not, brethren, that ye should be ignorant of this mystery, lest ye should be wise in your own conceits; that blindness in part is happened to Israel, until the fulness of the Gentiles be come in.
3 OCTOBER.part5:
In Romans 11:25, the Apostle Paul makes a clear distinction between Israel and the Gentiles. Paul, then declares that a spiritual blindness has fallen judicially upon the children of Israel because of their rejection of Christ and the Gospel. This spiritual blindness, however, is only in part because God has an elect remnant from the nation of Israel.

Paul also states that the judicial hardness upon Jews shall only last until the fullness of the Gentiles (or nations) comes into the visible Church. By bringing the Gentiles to Himself, the veil that had so blinded the Jews would be removed, and they will turn to Christ [2 Corinthians 3:14-16]. They too - like the Gentiles - would be brought to Christ and grafted back into the visible Church.

There is both a sense of duality and unity. Duality because God has not given up on the Jews and Gentiles are brought into the fold of salvation. And there is unity because Christ "is our peace, who hath made both one, and hath broken down the middle wall of partition between us (Jews and Gentiles)" and that the latter are "fellowheirs [with the Jews],and of the same body, and partakers of his promise in Christ by the gospel" [Ephesians 2:14; 3:6].

God is not done with Israel as a nation even though it is God's enemy presently due to its rejection of Christ and the Gospel. Israel is still God's covenantally beloved because of the promises the LORD had made to their fathers. The Psalmist writes: "My lovingkindness will I not utterly take from him, nor suffer my faithfulness to fail. My covenant will I not break, nor alter the thing that is gone out of my lips. Once have I sworn by my holiness that I will not lie unto David" [Psalm 89:33-35].
3 OCTOBER.part7: For all the promises of God in him are yea, and in him Amen, unto the glory of God by us. - 2 Corinthians 1:20

4 OCTOBER.part4: And so all Israel shall be saved: as it is written, There shall come out of Sion the Deliverer, and shall turn away ungodliness from Jacob
4 OCTOBER.part5:
The nation of Israel is in the news regularly, largely because of its struggle with its Arab neighbours, especially the Palestinians in the Gaza Strip and the West Bank. God's Word explicitly teaches that ancient Israel was God's chosen nation [Deuteronomy 7:6] and He has a special program and purpose for her to fulfill in history, but the Jews rejected Jesus Christ as their Messiah.

John says, "Jesus came unto his own, and his own received him not"[John 1:11]." When a choice was given them as to whom they wanted crucified, the Jews cried out, "Let him (Jesus) be crucified ... His blood be on us, and on our children [Matthew 27:22-25].

For this reason, throughout history, Christians have asked - "Is God finished with Israel?" There are Christians who believe that God is through with the Jews; that He has abandoned the nation. In Romans 11:1 Paul asks the question, "Hath God cast away his people?" [v. 1]. Paul would use three chapters [Romans 9, 10 and 11] to discuss God's dealings with that nation. Paul was concerned that we should not be ignorant of God's dealings with Israel.

To answer this question, let us consider first who was the Israel Paul was referring to in Romans 11:26. The word "Israel" occurs over 70 times in the New Testament. In almost every case, it refers to the old covenant nation or the physical descendants of Abraham through Isaac and Jacob. In Romans 9, 10 and 11, there are 12 references to Israel [Romans 9:4, 6, 27, 31; 10:1, 19, 21; 11:1, 2, 7, 25, 26]. It is also clear that when Paul speaks of Israel in Romans 9, 10, and 11, he is speaking of ethnic Israel. He is speaking of the Jews in distinction from the Gentiles. Israel in Romans 11:26 does not refer to the church.
4 OCTOBER.part7: God is faithful. "My covenant will I not break, nor alter the thing that is gone out of my lips. Once have I sworn by my holiness that I will not lie unto David". - Psalm 89:34-35

5 OCTOBER.part4: And so all Israel shall be saved: as it is written, There shall come out of Sion the Deliverer, and shall turn away ungodliness from Jacob
5 OCTOBER.part5:
God's Word certainly distinguishes between Israel and the church. The Apostle Paul describes the church as a mystery [see Ephesians 3:1-10; Colossians 1:24-27]. If that is the case, it begs the question: what does God have in store for Israel in the future?

Paul writes: "All Israel shall be saved". The question is who the "all Israel" Paul refers to. Does "all Israel" refer to every Jew? Does it mean that every Jew will be saved on account of his/her ethnicity? The answer is unquestionably no, just as we do not interpret "the world" in John 3:16 or 1 John 2:2, or "all men unto justification" [Romans 5:18], or "every man" [Hebrews 2:9] as referring to every person in the whole world. Such an interpretation would result in the error of universal salvation. The word "all" cannot be interpreted distributively, inclusively, or universally. Rather, "all" is to be interpreted restrictively.

Thus, when Paul says "all Israel shall be saved", the salvation experience he is talking about is the same salvation the Gentiles would have, which is to be delivered from sin, guilt and death by faith in Jesus Christ. To be saved means to be justified through the blood and righteousness of our Lord Jesus Christ. "All Israel shall be saved" are all those Paul described as the "remnant according to the election of grace" [v. 5].

There never has been, nor ever will be but one way of salvation. There is only one means of salvation because there is only one Saviour. And He, as Isaiah prophesied and quoted by Paul, "the Redeemer shall come to Zion, and unto them that turn from transgression in Jacob". [Isaiah 59:20]
5 OCTOBER.part7: Only one means of salvation. Only one Saviour. "For there is one God, and one mediator between God and men, the man Christ Jesus;" - 1 Timothy 2:5

6 OCTOBER.part4: And so all Israel shall be saved: as it is written, There shall come out of Sion the Deliverer, and shall turn away ungodliness from Jacob.
6 OCTOBER.part5:
The second part of Romans 11:26 is a quotation from Isaiah 59:20. "And the Redeemer shall come to Zion, and unto them that turn from transgression in Jacob, saith the LORD" [Isaiah 59:20]. In the context of Isaiah, the prophet is saying that the LORD will intervene - the Redeemer shall come to Zion, but even then there was a caveat; not all who claim to be of Zion will be saved; only those who "shall turn away ungodliness".

So "all Israel" does not mean every Jew, regardless of whether or not he has confessed Christ as Saviour, will be saved. It also does not mean that every Jew who is living at the return of Christ shall be saved.

The phrase "all Israel" parallels "the fullness of the Gentiles" [v. 25]. Paul is making the point that God has been saving, is saving, and will be saving both Jews and Gentiles, but only by and through faith in the atoning work of Jesus Christ. Paul will later allude to the organic unity of the elect. There will be one single good olive tree [v. 24], with the Jews being the "natural branches" [v. 21, 24], and the Gentiles being the branches of the wild olive tree [v. 17, 24]. Louis Berkhof comments, "'All Israel' is to be understood as a designation not of the whole nation but of the whole number of the elect out of the ancient covenant people...and the adverb 'so' cannot mean 'after that,' but only 'in this manner.'"

"Hath God cast away his people (the Jews)? God forbid" [v. 1, 11]. What about Gentiles (you and I)? By faith in Christ, salvation is come to us. Praise the LORD!
6 OCTOBER.part7: All that the Father giveth me shall come to me; and him that cometh to me I will in no wise cast out. - John 6:37.

7 OCTOBER.part4: And so all Israel shall be saved: as it is written, There shall come out of Sion the Deliverer, and shall turn away ungodliness from Jacob: For this is my covenant unto them, when I shall take away their sins.
7 OCTOBER.part5:
The phrase - "it is written" - one word in Greek is derived from the noun from which we get the English word "scripture" [see 2 Timothy 3:16], but the phrase does not simply mean that the words are recorded in some book somewhere, but rather that the words used are inscripturated somewhere else in divinely inspired Scripture.

Romans 11:26 is a quotation from Isaiah 59:20. When Romans 11:26b is juxtaposed with Isaiah 59:20, there is a minor difference. In Romans 11:26b, Paul says the Deliverer "shall come out of Sion" [Romans 11:26]. The exact words from Isaiah 59:20 are that the Redeemer "shall come to Zion" [Isaiah 59:20]. Paul has by inspiration of the Holy Spirit altered the preposition from "to" to "out of " Zion. The change came by way of Paul using words from another text of Scripture, namely, Psalm 14:7 - "Oh that the salvation of Israel were come out of Zion! when the LORD bringeth back the captivity of his people, Jacob shall rejoice, and Israel shall be glad." It is not unusual that NT verses are derived from a combination of OT verses; for example, Romans 9:33 is a combination of Isaiah 28:16 and 8:14. But Paul did not simply replace the prepositions, he did so by using Scripture itself. Paul has taken the words and meaning of Zion as found in Psalm 14:7 and combined them with the words from Isaiah 59:20.

Paul's intent is to show that the Redeemer who "shall come to Zion" [Isaiah 59:20] is also the Deliverer who "shall come out of Sion" [Romans 11:26; Psalm 14:7]. The Gospel according to John reminds us that Jesus came unto His own (Jews), but He was rejected. But "as many (Jews and Gentiles) as received Him and to believe on His name, they are "become the sons of God" [John 1:12]. Believe in Christ as your Redeemer, and you shall be a child of God.
7 OCTOBER.part7: Christ will come in great power to subdue sinful hearts, O Lord, hasten the day.

8 OCTOBER.part4: As concerning the gospel, they are enemies for your sakes: but as touching the election, they are beloved for the fathers' sakes.
8 OCTOBER.part5:
Paul, in Romans 11:28, makes an intriguing point which begs an equally intriguing question - "Can one person be both an enemy of the gospel and saved?" Paul's answer is categorically yes! Following the argument from the preceding verses, Paul says that the spiritual blindness and hardened hearts of Jews led to their rejection of the Lord Jesus Christ and the orchestration of the crucifixion of the Promised Messiah.

However, their animosity against Jesus worked for the spiritual benefit of Gentiles. In that sense, the Jews who rejected Christ were enemies of the Gospel. Paul told the Corinthians that the preaching of the crucified Christ was to "the Jews a stumblingblock" [1 Corinthians 1:23]. Furthermore, the Jews were opposed to the dissemination of the Gospel. Saul of Tarsus was a prime example.

The persecution of Christians and hostility against the Gospel, however, fueled its growth. Luke records for us that when the Jews turned against Paul and Barnabas [Acts 13:50], they declared that the Jews had judged themselves "unworthy of everlasting life" and so they turned to the Gentiles [Acts 13:46]. And when the Gentiles heard the Gospel, "they were glad, and glorified the word of the Lord: and as many as were ordained to eternal life believed" [Acts 13:48].

In spite of the animosity of Jews against Christ and His Gospel, Paul adds "they are beloved", meaning that the same Jews who were once enemies of the Gospel had become beloved of God - a great change on account of God's eternal and immutable decree that former enemies (who we were) can become friends (what we are now).
8 OCTOBER.part7: For God commendeth his love toward us, in that, while we were yet sinners, Christ died for us. - Romans 5:8

9 OCTOBER.part4: As concerning the gospel, they are enemies for your sakes: but as touching the election, they are beloved for the fathers' sakes.
9 OCTOBER.part5:
In his searing indictment against the Jews on Pentecost, Peter said, "Ye men of Israel .. Jesus of Nazareth, a man approved of God among you by miracles and wonders and signs, which God did by him in the midst of you, as ye yourselves also know: Him .. ye have taken, and by wicked hands have crucified and slain" [Acts 2:22-23]. Peter did not mince his words. He was saying that the Jews (men of Israel) were, as far as the Gospel is concerned, enemies of Christ.

However, as far as election is concerned, they were beloved for the sake of their fathers. In verses 30 and 31, the "enemies" and the "beloved" ones are the same people, namely, they are God's elect. They were at first hostile to the Gospel, but later, because of the wonderful manifestation of God's mercy, they become friends.

The same Jews who at one time were enemies of the Gospel had become friends, beloved of God, and fellow believers. This great change will occur because the former enmity and the subsequent friendship had been decreed by God's covenant.

They were beloved "for the fathers' sake". This does not mean that there was some innate goodness or merit pertaining to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob but solely because of God's promise to the fathers. God told Abraham, "And I will establish my covenant between me and thee and thy seed after thee in their generations for an everlasting covenant, to be a God unto thee, and to thy seed after thee" [Genesis 17:7]. Like the Jews, we too are rejected - enemies of God - on account of our disobedience, but we are loved on account of God's grace.
9 OCTOBER.part7: We deserve every ounce of God's righteous wrath because of who we are and what we have done. That we are saved is by God's grace alone.

10 OCTOBER.part4: For the gifts and calling of God are without repentance. For as ye in times past have not believed God, yet have now obtained mercy through their unbelief:
10 OCTOBER.part5:
Romans 11:29 must be understood in light of God's covenantal promises to Israel. The "gifts and calling" refer to the privileges Israel enjoyed as God's chosen people. They were given the oracles of God [Romans 3:2]. To them were given "the glory, and the covenants, and the giving of the law, and the service of God, and the promises" [Romans 9:4]. However, they did not treasure their God-given privileges. Israel had a history of rebellion against God and rejection of His promised Messiah.

By human judgment, the promises God made to Israel should have been justly abrogated. Israel rightly deserved God's judgment. But this was not so. Romans 11:29 says that the privileges God has given Israel are "that is repentance". This is one word in Greek that is used only twice in the New Testament in this verse and in 2 Corinthians 7:10. The phrase simply means "irrevocable". Even when they had rejected the Messiah, they themselves were not rejected. "Hath God cast away his people?" Paul asked rhetorically. "God forbid" (v. 1).

This is God's faithfulness. God cannot lie [Titus 1:2; Psalm 89:35; Hebrews 6:18]. As Israel settled in the Promised Land, Joshua reminded the people, "There failed not ought of any good thing which the LORD had spoken unto the house of Israel; all came to pass" [Joshua 21:45]. God will not abandon His people [Hebrews 13:5]. Our unbelief does not nullify God's promises [Romans 3:3]. "If we believe not, yet he abideth faithful: he cannot deny himself ". - [2 Timothy 2:13]

The veracity of God and the truthfulness of His promises is the assurance of God's continued relationship despite our vacillating loyalty.
10 OCTOBER.part7: Our hope in God is not that we hold on to Him but that He holds on to us.

11 OCTOBER.part4: Even so have these also now not believed, that through your mercy they also may obtain mercy. For God hath concluded them all in unbelief, that he might have mercy upon all.
11 OCTOBER.part5:
The history of mankind - Jews and Gentiles alike - can be summed up in one phrase - rebellion against God. " For all have sinned, and come short of the glory of God" [Romans 3:23]. The disobeience of the Gentile, however, is somewhat different from the disobedience of Israel.

The disobedience of Gentiles is marked by godless idolatry. Paul says that Gentiles are "by nature the children of wrath .. aliens from the commonwealth of Israel, and strangers from the covenants of promise, having no hope, and without God in the world" [Ephesians 2:3, 12].

Israel's disobedience is characterized by the rejection of Jesus of Nazareth as the Promised Messiah and the apostolic preaching of His resurrection, which to them was a stumbling block [see 1 Corinthians 1:23]. The Jews were hardened and unbelieving; God chose them to be His own; He gave them the Law; He sent the prophets; He promised them His Son, but they despised them all and spoke "evil of that Way" [Acts 19:9].

Sinners - Jews or Gentiles - are responsible for their sins. We have lost all claim on God. If we are to be saved, it will not be on account of our own righteousness but on the principle of mercy - God's mercy to the Gentiles came by way of Israel's hardened rejection and disobedience of Christ. The Jews receive mercy by the example of mercy that God has shown to Gentiles.

In either case, regardless of the nature of disobedience, salvation comes to sinners only because God, in His rich mercy and great love, seeks and calls us to saving faith. Sinners are "dead in trespasses and sins ... But God, who is rich in mercy, for his great love wherewith he loved us ... hath quickened us together with Christ. [Ephesians 2:15]
11 OCTOBER.part7: God has dealt with us in grace (unearned favor) and He has shown mercy when we have no hope.

12 OCTOBER.part4: O the depth of the riches both of the wisdom and knowledge of God! how unsearchable are his judgments, and his ways past finding out! For who hath known the mind of the Lord? or who hath been his counseller?
12 OCTOBER.part5:
When Paul reflects on the mercy of God to Israel and Gentiles, he broke out in exuberant praise of God's wisdom. The last four verses of Romans 11 can rightly be classified as a hymn of praise.

Paul makes a distinction between God's wisdom and knowledge. The biblical concept of knowledge (Gk: gnosis) is more than just an understanding of what is factual and true. It is personal rather than principal, existential rather than philosophical, God-centred rather than man-centred. It is manifested in Christ - the eternal Logos, who is "full of grace and truth" [John 1:14; Hebrews 1:1]. Thus, the knowledge of God denotes His omniscience - His divine insight of all things.

The wisdom of God is His ability to direct all things to His perfect end. God chooses the best means to attain the best goals. It has been described as divine effectiveness. "All things (will) work together for good to them that love God, to them who are the called according to his purpose" [Romans 8:28]. Like divine knowledge, God's wisdom is also personified in the Person of Christ.

Because of the depth of God's wisdom and knowledge, His ways and judgments are beyond human comprehension. His thoughts are not our thoughts, and His ways are higher than our ways [see Isaiah 55:8-9]. What man indeed has the ability to probe the mind of God? And who has the ability to act as the divine counsellor? The finite nature of mankind can never understand the ways of an infinite God. Man cannot trace the ways and judgments of God. So rather than irreverently investigating the unknown, we humbly bow and receive what God has chosen to reveal to us.
12 OCTOBER.part7: The secret things belong unto the LORD our God: but those things which are revealed belong unto us and to our children for ever, that we may do all the words of this law. - Deuteronomy 29:29

13 OCTOBER.part4: Or who hath first given to him, and it shall be recompensed unto him again? For of him, and through him, and to him, are all things: to whom be glory for ever. Amen.
13 OCTOBER.part5:
In the closing verses of Romans 11, Paul brings us to the pinnacle of praise as he talks about the mercy of God in bringing together the Jews and Gentiles as one body in Christ. As Paul considers God's mind, ways, and wisdom, as he considers God's eternal decree and counsel, he asks, "who hath first given to him, and it shall be recompensed unto him again?" Paul is asking a rhetorical question - is there someone who can give to God in such a way that God becomes indebted to him? The answer is a resounding NO!

The question is important because this is precisely what some people think who have a quid pro quo attitude in their relationship with God. They seek to make God a debtor - "If I do this or that, God will owe me His favour."

But God is not a debtor because He is the Creator. All things are of Him, come through Him, and unto Him. We cannot give to God what already belongs to Him. The Psalmist reminds us that "every beast of the forest is (God's), and the cattle upon a thousand hills" [Psalm 50:10]. David, when he had given to the building of the temple, said, "But who am I, and what is my people, that we should be able to offer so willingly after this sort? for all things come of thee, and of thine own have we given thee" [1 Chronicles 29:14].

God is also not a debtor to our "righteousness". The righteousness of our hands is as filthy rags [Isaiah 64:6]. No amount of good deeds we do can oblige God to save us [Titus 3:5]. Salvation is completely a work of God. God cannot be made a debtor. He owes us nothing but His condemnation.
13 OCTOBER.part7:
All of God's judgement upon us is our own doing.
All of God's goodness to us is by His grace.

14 OCTOBER.part4: I beseech you therefore, brethren, by the mercies of God, that ye present your bodies a living sacrifice, holy, acceptable unto God, which is your reasonable service.
14 OCTOBER.part5:
In the first 11 chapters of Romans, Paul provided his readers and those generations later the most comprehensive and precise statement of the Gospel and doctrines of the church for understanding man's condition, his needs, and God's provision of the answer. In the second part of this letter (chapters 12 to 16), he turns his attention to the practical application of those doctrines and how a Christian should live the righteous life God desires. Knowing the theory, what then were they to do in practice? "Therefore ... present your bodies a living sacrifice, holy, acceptable unto God".

The idea of worship sacrifices was nothing new to the Jews and the Gentiles. The Jews according to the Law offered them in contrition for sin, thankfulness for blessing, acknowledgement of God's divinity, and worship to Jehovah. Gentiles offered sacrifices to appease their deities, seek their blessing, and secure their goodwill.

The supreme final atoning sacrifice for mankind's sin had been made by Christ. Salvation's work was finished at the cross. Lifeless sacrifices were done with. But those for whom Christ died are now to offer themselves to God in love and obedience to Him, in service and blessing to others as an ambassador for Christ. A living sacrifice is to place our hearts, bodies, our all, even life itself at God's disposal, withholding nothing for His glory. And it is the sanctified and consecrated life in which sins are repented of, walking in God's way, ruled by His Word, which is holy and acceptable to Him.

Just as our heavenly Father has done in giving and accepting the living sacrifice His beloved Son made for us, we are to do likewise to the best of our ability.
14 OCTOBER.part7: He hath shewed thee, O man, what is good; and what doth the LORD require of thee, but to do justly, and to love mercy, and to walk humbly with thy God? - Micah 6:8

15 OCTOBER.part4: I beseech you therefore, brethren, by the mercies of God, that ye present your bodies a living sacrifice, holy, acceptable unto God, which is your reasonable service.
15 OCTOBER.part5:
The offering of us to God as a living sacrifice is the Christian's "reasonable service". What are the meaning and implications of this? The word rendered "reasonable" does not hold the meaning we have in usage today. It is not opposed to being "unreasonable" as though we who have received such a great salvation have a choice and ought to be persuaded to serve as a quid pro quo, although that certainly should be so.

Rather, the word "reasonable" pertains to that which emanates from reason. It is rational service and worship informed and guided by God's Word. It is therefore sincere spiritual worship from a renewed heart enlightened with God's Word, not the exercise of empty rituals and external observation of do's and dont's devoid of love for God and concern for man, which the Jews' religion had descended to. Neither is it the senseless idol-worship of the Gentile heathens. So Peter says we are lively stones, built up, an holy priesthood, to offer up sacrifices, acceptable to God [1 Peter 2:5].

Offering worship is not an option but an obligation. We belong to Him who has purchased and delivered us from the tyranny of the devil. In the Apostle's words "Being then made free from sin, ye became the servants of righteousness" [Romans 6:18]. We serve Him because we are saved. We become a living sacrifice by worshipping and serving with all our heart, body, and mind. Empty profession is not "reasonable service" but vanity and false religion. Our God delights in the Christian's heart worship and devotion, not his lip-service.
15 OCTOBER.part7: Jesus said, "This people draweth nigh unto me with their mouth, and honoureth me with their lips; but their heart is far from me. But in vain they do worship me, teaching for doctrines the commandments of men." - Matthew 15:8-9

16 OCTOBER.part4: And be not conformed to this world: but be ye transformed by the renewing of your mind, that ye may prove what is that good, and acceptable, and perfect, will of God.
16 OCTOBER.part5:
A person takes his identity from what he is most closely associated with. The things most dear and near to his heart often shape the person he becomes. They direct his thoughts, occupy his desires, mold his values, and determine his behaviour. A worldly person naturally identifies with the world and conforms to its principles and practices, methods and means, values and interests, customs and lifestyle, appearance and speech.

We are born to our earthly parents and take on in many ways after them. We are also born into a world of sin with the sin seed of our first father Adam in us. Jesus told the self-righteous Pharisees, "Ye are of your father the devil, and the lusts of your father ye will do ..." [John 8:44].

It is therefore no wonder that as born sinners we will love the world - the lust of the flesh, the lust of the eyes and the pride of life. [1 John 2:15-16] We take to sin as a fish takes to water.

But when we receive salvation in Jesus Christ, we are freed from the old life and the old ways. We are to break our conformity with the world and offer ourselves as living sacrifices for God's use. We are to turn our backs on all those things we once held dear that go against God's Word and be conformed to Christ in every possible way. And we are able to do so because the Holy Spirit who enables us now dwells in us. In our own strength, this is an impossibility, but praise be to God for with Him all things are possible, even changing and conforming born-again sinners that we are to the likeness of His Son.
16 OCTOBER.part7: There are two omnipotences with Him: 'With God all things are possible .... All things are possible to him that believeth. - Vance Havner, By The Way: Meditations of a Christian Pilgrim

17 OCTOBER.part4: And be not conformed to this world: but be ye transformed by the renewing of your mind, that ye may prove what is that good, and acceptable, and perfect, will of God.
17 OCTOBER.part5:
Jesus told Nicodemus, "That which is born of the flesh is flesh; and that which is born of the Spirit is spirit. Marvel not that I said unto thee, Ye must be born again" [John 3:6-7].

Spiritual rebirth is the pre-requisite for eternal life. In our first birth, we were born physically alive, but we were already spiritually dead. When Jesus becomes our personal Lord and Saviour, we are born again; we become a child of God and a citizen of His kingdom. A supernatural act happened. "Therefore if any man be in Christ, he is a new creature: old things are passed away; behold, all things are become new" [2 Corinthians 5:17].

The mark of the new creature in Christ is transformation. He undergoes a total change. The spiritual man is transformed by the renewing of his mind. His thinking, affections and loyalties are now aligned with those of the new King of his life and his new identity. His heart, mind, and will are changed by the knowledge of the Gospel, the enlightenment of God's Word, the power of the Holy Spirit, and by the concerns of the age and kingdom to come. He renounces the habits and likings of his old life. He turns his back on his former ways and preoccupations. The transient treasures and fleeting affections of this life hold no more allure for him. He is able to discern God's sovereign and perfect will and demonstrates this in his living and being. He is in the world but not of this world. This is the miraculous transformation which God has wrought.
17 OCTOBER.part7: If ye then be risen with Christ, seek those things which are above, where Christ sitteth on the right hand of God. Set your affection on things above, not on things on the earth. For ye are dead, and your life is hid with Christ in God. - Colossians 3:1-3.

18 OCTOBER.part4: For I say, through the grace given unto me, to every man that is among you, not to think of himself more highly than he ought to think; but to think soberly, according as God hath dealt to every man the measure of faith.
18 OCTOBER.part5:
The natural man thinks more highly of himself than he ought. He looks at others and thinks he is better than them. Then he looks at himself and thinks he is really not so bad after all. This is the root of pride. Pride elevates self. Pride which leads to idolatry - the worship of self.

The biblical injunction and antidote against pride is to think soberly about ourselves. What does it mean to "think soberly"? It is to consider seriously and wisely who and what we are. It is making a realistic and honest judgment of ourselves as God sees us. It is realizing that we were lost in sin before we were found by God, that we were under bondage to Satan before our deliverance in Christ. Our uncleanness was odious before Christ's sinless blood washed us white as snow. We were objects of God's wrath before our adoption as sons and daughters of His divine love.

And now that God has wrought such as a great salvation in us, how are we to offer our lives to God as an offering of sweet fragrance? We are to consider the "measure of faith" God has endowed us with and think with humility and meekness how we can serve God and man with these gifts. And Paul enumerates these gifts of grace in the following verses.

We must be mindful of the spirit of Lucifer who, though endowed with wondrous gifts, failed to think soberly, but coveted the place of God. And let us have the mind of Christ who though He was God, humbled Himself as a servant to die for our sakes.
18 OCTOBER.part7: Let nothing be done through strife or vainglory; but in lowliness of mind let each esteem other better than themselves. Look not every man on his own things, but every man also on the things of others. Let this mind be in you, which was also in Christ Jesus. - Philippians 2:3-5

19 OCTOBER.part4: So we, being many, are one body in Christ, and every one members one of another.
19 OCTOBER.part5:
Many members, one body! There are three aspects of the human body which is a picture of the church of Christ. Firstly, its beauty. After God completed his creation of man and woman, He saw that it was "very good" [Genesis 1:31]. The church of God's redeemed, purchased by Christ's blood, assembled together in worship and service to represent her Lord on earth is beautiful in God's eyes. Every true member of this church is wonderfully created in God's image and therefore should reflect His glorious work by their sanctified lives abounding with the fruit of the Spirit.

Second, its unity. The human body comprises different organs all functioning differently, yet they interact harmoniously with each other. Likewise, the church functions well when the members do their part with oneness of spirit and mind, each esteeming others better than themselves [Philippians 2:3] striving together for the faith of the Gospel [Philippians 1:27]. Our Lord Jesus prays that "they all may be one" [John 17:21].

Thirdly, its sanctity. When Jesus returned to His heavenly throne, God despatched the Holy Spirit to dwell in every believer's heart. Thrice Paul reminds the Corinthians that their bodies were the temple of the Holy Spirit [1 Corinthians 6:19, 2 Corinthians 6:16]. The church which is the assembly of individual believers must therefore be a sanctified body. Its mission, activities, and duty must be to do the Master's work according to His will and way.

When the church manifests these three characteristics, then she will be the chaste bride of Christ.
19 OCTOBER.part7: That they all may be one; as thou, Father, art in me, and I in thee, that they also may be one in us: that the world may believe that thou hast sent me. - John 17:21

20 OCTOBER.part4: Having then gifts differing according to the grace that is given to us, whether prophecy, let us prophesy according to the proportion of faith;
20 OCTOBER.part5:
The body of Christ ought not only to be united, but the Apostle also stresses its diversity. And these two go hand in hand.

Unity is not uniformity or homogeneity. The assembly of believers comprises a mix of people with different qualities, temperaments, characters, and thinking, yet they are united in heart, mind and spirit. Every individual is unique, yet co-exists with others serving the same Lord God, in the power of the same Spirit because they were saved by the same Christ.

There is strength and safety in diversity. It is strong because different strengths and abilities can be brought to bear in adversity. Each is strengthened by the other and the three-fold cord is stronger still [Ecclesiastes 4:9-12]. It is safe because '"Where no counsel is, the people fall: but in the multitude of counsellors there is safety [Proverbs 11:14; 15:22].

Diversity is also effective and efficient. It is effective because we serve and witness to a diverse people. Some are better able than others to reach these. It is efficient because the diversity of gifts facilitates the division of labour and distribution of duties. Diversity was God's wise design. He chose His prophets from sundry backgrounds to speak His Word in revelation, prediction and warning. Christ called twelve apostles from different walks of life to build His through the Gospel proclamation. And God's servants were bestowed with diverse gifts by the Holy Spirit. From all peoples and backgrounds, God chooses and uses whom He will. He calls us who are His representatives to serve Him, each with our individual gifts but all working together for His glory.
20 OCTOBER.part7: From whom the whole body fitly joined together and compacted by that which every joint supplieth, according to the effectual working in the measure of every part, maketh increase of the body unto the edifying of itself in love. - Ephesians 4:16.

21 OCTOBER.part4: Or ministry, let us wait on our ministering: or he that teacheth, on teaching;
21 OCTOBER.part5:
Ministry is to do the work of a servant or attendant. From Greek word - diakonia - we get "deacon". The idea of servanthood goes against human nature because we would rather be served than to serve. A servant waits upon others. A servant takes care of the welfare of others in a low and humble office. It is work without status, often despised, usually without appreciation.

Yet this describes exactly what the Son of God did for us in His incarnation, from His lowly birth to His humiliating death. Jesus set the supreme example for our emulation and told His disciples, "Even as the Son of man came not to be ministered unto, but to minister, and to give his life a ransom for many" [Matthew 20:28].

Having the spirit and heart of a servant in our Christian conduct is to be most Christ-like. If Jesus could be a servant to man, then everyone who professes Christ's name can and must be a servant.

Teaching - a teacher is one who instructs or communicates knowledge. He has the responsibility to open up the Scriptures and expound on its doctrines for our understanding and guidance. Those who teach therefore carry a grave responsibility lest they lead others astray or cause some to stumble. And they will be held to greater accountability by the Lord. Therefore, those who aspire to this office have the warning from James 3:1: "My brethren, be not many masters, knowing that we shall receive the greater condemnation." The responsibility and respect of this office carry a price. It is not something to be coveted carelessly without serious consideration of its consequences.
21 OCTOBER.part7: If I then, your Lord and Master, have washed your feet; ye also ought to wash one another's feet. For I have given you an example, that ye should do as I have done to you. - John 13:14-15

22 OCTOBER.part4: Or he that exhorteth, on exhortation: he that giveth, let him do it with simplicity; he that ruleth, with diligence; he that sheweth mercy, with cheerfulness.
22 OCTOBER.part5:
Today's reading continues Paul's admonition by highlighting two things - First, the diversity of gifts we are variously bestowed with, and second, the spirit we must have in exercising them.

God has given every person one or more gifts to be used in and outside the church as this verse informs. Some have a natural ability to encourage and admonish through practical help and advice, to encourage the feeble brother, and to stir up another to duty. Others are entrusted within the church to deal with finances. There are still others who have been blessed by God with the means to help and support others, financially or otherwise.

Regardless of the ministry, we are to serve with singleness of mind and purity of heart, without ostentation, selfish intentions, or ulterior motives. To be "simple" is not to be calculating. Those entrusted with the responsibility of administration are to be conscientious, realising that we serve and answer to our Master, the Lord Jesus.

If we have the ministry of comforting those in need - the afflicted, distressed and sorrowing - with a kind word or helping hand, do it willingly, cheerfully, and patiently. Covering the exercise of all our gifts must be our prayerfulness. Be generous and spontaneous, not begrudging any expense of time, talents, and treasures for the name of Christ.

We must also serve with humility and love. Humility, because all we possess are given by the Lord. We are merely stewards and have nothing to boast about. Love because our Lord first loved us and gave Himself freely for us. In turn, we are to love Him and our neighbour by the use of our gifts in obedience to His Word.
22 OCTOBER.part7: Now there are diversities of gifts, but the same Spirit. And there are differences of administrations, but the same Lord. And there are diversities of operations, but it is the same God which worketh all in all. - 1 Corinthians 12:4-6

23 OCTOBER.part4: Let love be without dissimulation. Abhor that which is evil; cleave to that which is good.
23 OCTOBER.part5:
Our sinful, unbelieving world is marred with much hypocrisy and pretence. People readily put on a mask and a show of affection, but it is often not genuine. Like the seductress of Proverbs 5, whose lips are sweet as honeycomb, and mouth smoother than oil, she entices men with love that is not genuine, and the end of it is bitter as wormwood.

The Apostle Paul's words in Romans 12:9 are a powerful reminder to us to love our fellowmen, without hypocrisy or dissimulation. We are to show genuine love for our neighbours, love which is sincere and unconditional. Love that does not put on a facade with the hidden motive of personal gain.

How do we love without dissimulation? We begin by putting ourselves in others' shoes. We empathise with them; we understand the situation they are going through. Once we do this, we will know their needs and can genuinely care for their well-being, seeking their highest good without any personal agenda or ulterior motive.

In interacting with others, pray that God would search our hearts, and show us how to love our neighbour selflessly and genuinely, putting aside any selfish consideration. Only then, can we be God's channels of blessings, to bring the light of the Gospel to a dark and unbelieving world.
23 OCTOBER.part7: Wherefore putting away lying, speak every man truth with his neighbour: for we are members one of another. - Ephesians 4:25

24 OCTOBER.part4: Be kindly affectioned one to another with brotherly love; in honour preferring one another;
24 OCTOBER.part5:
Today's reading exhorts us to be "kindly affectioned one to another with brotherly love". In this busy and self-serving world, where material pursuits dominate the thoughts and minds of most people, kindness takes a back seat. Most people, it seems, seek personal gain at the cost of others, and kindness is often ignored. However, Christians are to be different because we are called to a higher standard.

Kindness is not an afterthought or something we dispense whenever we have the capacity to do so. It flows from the genuine love that Paul mentions in Romans 12:9 because without a heart filled with selfless, sincere, and unconditional love, it will be difficult for one to show kindness to his fellowmen.

Showing kindness involves putting others before self, and going out of our way to help those in need, to alleviate the suffering of others, often at the expense of our own convenience and comfort.

Let us examine ourselves. Learn from and follow the example of our Lord Jesus who came down from heaven to minister to those who were suffering, healing the sick, showing compassion to the widows and the fatherless, and saving the lost. We must be sensitive to those around us who are in need, and lend a helping hand, extend a listening ear to someone who is hurting, and offer a word of kindness and encouragement to those who are discouraged. May others see Jesus in us, as we show kindness to them.
24 OCTOBER.part7: As we have therefore opportunity, let us do good unto all men, especially unto them who are of the household of faith. - Galatians 6:10

25 OCTOBER.part4: Not slothful in business; fervent in spirit; serving the Lord;
25 OCTOBER.part5:
In our busy lives in which we are often surrounded with much earthly cares, it is easy to fall into the trap of slothfulness, especially when it comes to the Lord's work. Slothfulness is not just physical laziness. Paul here refers to our spiritual walk with God and how it affects our effectiveness for Him. Romans 12:11 reminds us of the importance of being diligent in everything we do, especially when doing God's work.

The Apostle Paul exhorts us not to be slothful in every aspect of our lives. We are to be industrious and conscientious in our daily work and responsibilities. This too is a testimony to our Lord Jesus Christ. God desires that we approach our tasks with earnest dedication and excellence, because ultimately it is work He has ordained for us to do. "And whatsoever ye do, do it heartily, as to the Lord, and not unto men" [Colossians 3:23].

Look into our own lives and see if we have been slothful in any aspect of our work, life and spiritual walk. Have we become complacent in service to God? Have we allowed the world to creep in and lessen our commitment to our Lord? Or have we been fervent and zealous for our God, serving Him with the diligence and devotion that He deserves? May the Lord help us to awake from slothful slumber and rekindle in our hearts with the fire and zeal His Kingdom deserves.
25 OCTOBER.part7: Whatsoever thy hand findeth to do, do it with thy might; for there is no work, nor device, nor knowledge, nor wisdom, in the grave, whither thou goest. - Ecclesiastes 9:10

26 OCTOBER.part4: Rejoicing in hope; patient in tribulation; continuing instant in prayer;
26 OCTOBER.part5:
Hope is the strength that keeps us going. That is why many in this world are willing to go to great lengths to "buy" hope. We had trusted in human wisdom and solutions, thinking these would save us out of some troubles, or set us at peace. Yet we know there is no lasting hope without Christ for our Lord Jesus is the one who has secured the peace that will last for eternity, reconciling us to God, and giving us the sure blessed hope of everlasting life when we trust in Him. For this reason, we can rejoice - even in tough times, for indeed "all things are for your sakes, that the abundant grace might through the thanksgiving of many redound to the glory of God" [2 Corinthians 4:15].

Yet our struggles in life are also real, especially in these last days when "we must through much tribulation enter into the kingdom of God" [Acts 14:22]. But no matter how great the trials we face, realize these will also come to an end, and even if we cannot help but be worried and anxious, may the hope we have cause us to be patient and wait upon the LORD, for everything is under His sovereign control, and He is working all things together for good to them that love Him, to them who are the called according to His purpose [Romans 8:28].

In times of need, we are not without help. God has granted us His means of grace: prayer. We come before Him, casting everything before His throne of grace - and continue doing that no matter what circumstances we face. We need to pray when we think we need God. And we need to pray even more when we think we do not need Him.
26 OCTOBER.part7: Rejoice evermore. Pray without ceasing. In every thing give thanks: for this is the will of God in Christ Jesus concerning you. - 1 Thessalonians 5:16-18

27 OCTOBER.part4: Distributing to the necessity of saints; given hospitality.
27 OCTOBER.part5:
The ability to give is a blessing from God, and interestingly, this is one of the main reasons for our labours. Ephesians 4:28 exhorts us, "Let him that stole steal no more: but rather let him labour, working with his hands the thing which is good, that he may have to give to him that needeth." There is a wonderful transition here from one who needs help and who even resorts to unlawful means to meet their needs, to one who will work and give to others. We work to not only provide for ourselves and our loved ones but also to give and help others.

Among those whom we give to, we are especially reminded to give for the cause of Christ. "As we have therefore opportunity, let us do good unto all men, especially unto them who are of the household of faith" [Galatians 6:10]. It is true that our generosity may touch the hearts of unbelievers and cause them to turn to Christ, but more so we should help a brother in need - for it may be God's will that we are to be a channel of providence to him, perhaps the answer to his prayers - and that in receiving this blessing through our hands, he may give thanks and glory to God.

The gift of hospitality was especially important during Paul's time because places to live were not readily available, and Christians needed the protection of other brethren against persecution. It is also important in our times to extend the warm hand of fellowship to fellow sojourners in this world. If we keep in mind that we are but stewards of God's manifold blessings, we will give willingly and cheerfully to those who are in need.
27 OCTOBER.part7: I have shewed you all things, how that so labouring ye ought to support the weak, and to remember the words of the Lord Jesus, how he said, It is more blessed to give than to receive. - Acts 20:35

28 OCTOBER.part4: Bless them which persecute you: bless, and curse not.
28 OCTOBER.part5:
To many, the call to bless our persecutors seems a tall order. It is difficult enough for one to not return evil for evil, what more to bless someone who is against you, and against the cause of Christ. But this was how Paul lived his life. Writing to his protege Timothy, he reminded him how "all that will live godly in Christ Jesus shall suffer persecution" [2 Timothy 3:12]. The elder shared how he had endured the afflictions, and how out of them all the Lord had delivered him [2 Timothy 3:11]. Indeed, the unfair treatment he received despite his good intentions, though painful, had caused him to turn to God and trust Him for deliverance.

It should give us great comfort that the Lord Jesus concluded the Beatitudes with these words: "Blessed are they which are persecuted for righteousness' sake: for theirs' is the kingdom of heaven" [Matthew 5:10]. This final beatitude is also the only one He further elaborated on: "Blessed are ye, when men shall revile you, and persecute you, and shall say all manner of evil against you falsely, for my sake. Rejoice, and be exceeding glad: for great is your reward in heaven: for so persecuted they the prophets which were before you" [Matthew 5:11-12].

Fixing our eyes on the glory that shall be revealed in the day of Christ, we are thus able to not only endure but also bless and give thanks, able to pray for ourselves and for our persecutors, that the love of Christ will strengthen us and change them. It is a tall order but it is the high calling of Christ for His followers.
28 OCTOBER.part7: Looking unto Jesus the author and finisher of our faith; who for the joy that was set before him endured the cross, despising the shame, and is set down at the right hand of the throne of God. - Hebrews 12:2

29 OCTOBER.part4: Rejoice with them that do rejoice, and weep with them that weep.
29 OCTOBER.part5:
This verse cites two actions, but the emphasis is on the motivation behind them - empathy that we have with fellow humankind. In rejoicing with those who rejoice and weeping with those who weep, we step out of ourselves, and into the lives of others. Their joy and sorrows become ours.

To participate in the joy of others is a privilege. How blessed it is to be truly happy for someone else! On the other hand, to understand and feel the sorrows of others is also a blessing, for God has moved you to care for someone other than self who needs comfort and strength. Thus seize all opportunities to be involved in the lives of others: if they are unbelievers, they will see your genuine concern for them and perchance may want to know the Source of your motivation; if of the same household of faith, they will give thanks to God for your presence in that particular time of their life.

Yet how much of our time is spent doing otherwise? In our sinful state, we gloat at the misfortune of others; we fold our hands in indifference and even indignation when others triumph, passing judgment whether it was deserved or not. The amount of time and thoughts expended in such malice and resentment can be channelled to better use, for the Bible has told us we should love others as we love ourselves.

If these actions are not found in your life, then step forward to do them, for in blessing those who rejoice and caring for those who weep, in sharing one another's laughter and tears, we bear one another's burden, and thus are fulfilling the law of Christ. [Galatians 6:2.]
29 OCTOBER.part7: For all the law is fulfilled in one word, even in this; Thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyself. - Galatians 5:14

30 OCTOBER.part4: Be of the same mind one toward another. Mind not high things, but condescend to men of low estate. Be not wise in your own conceits.
30 OCTOBER.part5:
The vice that we are warned against here is pride - arguably the greatest sin, for it was pride that caused Lucifer to fall [Isaiah 14, Ezekiel 38]. It was pride that led to the fall of Adam and Eve because they wanted to be as gods [Genesis 3:5]. It was the sin that David prayed for God to keep him back from [Psalm 19:13], and it was what caused the Pharisees to want to kill the Lord Jesus [Matthew 23:13].

Today, pride is still the sin that causes strife between people and contentions even within God's church.

Paul in Philippians 2:2-5 is especially pertinent to this matter: "Fulfil ye my joy, that ye be likeminded, having the same love, being of one accord, of one mind. Let nothing be done through strife or vainglory; but in lowliness of mind let each esteem other better than themselves. Look not every man on his own things, but every man also on the things of others. Let this mind be in you, which was also in Christ Jesus."

Being of the same mind is having the same kingdom of God in our thoughts. In our interaction with others, we seek to edify and encourage. Instead of thinking of ourselves, we are reminded to "condescend" to people who are of low estate - be it spiritually, socially, or intellectually. Indeed, it may be difficult if the difference is obvious, but we are reminded how Christ humbled Himself and came to us wretched sinners to die for us.

How great was that condescension! And in that light, how small are our differences with one another! Be not wise in your own conceits. "Seest thou a man wise in his own conceit? there is more hope of a fool than of him" [Proverbs 26:12].
30 OCTOBER.part7: THOUGHT   But he giveth more grace. Wherefore he saith, God resisteth the proud, but giveth grace unto the humble. - James 4:6

31 OCTOBER.part4: Recompense to no man evil for evil. Provide things honest in the sight of all men.
31 OCTOBER.part5:
We live in a world where self is much emphasized. We orientate our lives around ourselves, and fight for our own interests. When we are deprived of what we think should belong to us, we respond by taking from others what rightfully belongs to them. So, when someone does not respect us, we in turn despise them, and this becomes a vicious cycle that grows with each round.

To break this cycle, we must "recompense to no man evil for evil", and God's children are in the best position to do that, for that was exactly what our Lord did. "He was oppressed, and he was afflicted, yet he opened not his mouth: he is brought as a lamb to the slaughter, and as a sheep before her shearers is dumb, so he openeth not his mouth" [Isaiah 53:7]. Our Lord could have taken things in His own hands to smite His oppressors, but He did not, for He had set His eyes on the salvation of mankind. For the sake of His Father's kingdom and righteousness, He was willing to sacrifice Himself.

Additionally, we are commanded to "provide things honest in the sight of all men." "Honest" is the word "kalos" which is a general term meaning "right", "good" or "beautiful". Paul exhorts us to give to others what they consider to be right, good, and beautiful. In God's common grace, we can see that He does this in giving common blessings to all. Paul thus tells us to hold to what is good, instead of plotting that which is evil.
31 OCTOBER.part7: Finally, brethren, whatsoever things are true, whatsoever things are honest, whatsoever things are just, whatsoever things are pure, whatsoever things are lovely, whatsoever things are of good report; if there be any virtue, and if there be any praise, think on these things. - Philippians 4:8

1 NOVEMBER.part4: If it be possible, as much as lieth in you, live peaceably with all men.
1 NOVEMBER.part5:
Peace is something that characterises a Christian. We are reconciled with God and thus at peace with our Creator. And because the void in our hearts is filled by God, we are at peace with ourselves. With this peace, we can find strength and wisdom to live with one another, and eventually with the rest of creation. It is also with this peace that we can choose not to return evil for evil, and even overcome evil with good.

Paul also recognises that there are times when it may be difficult to live peaceably with others. For one, the world may not want to live peaceably with us by making things difficult for us. In John 15:18-19, our Lord Jesus said, "If the world hate you, ye know that it hated me before it hated you. If ye were of the world, the world would love his own: but because ye are not of the world, but I have chosen you out of the world, therefore the world hateth you."

Even so, we ought to maintain a good testimony of peace for the Lord. And "sanctify the Lord God in your hearts: and be ready always to give an answer to every man that asketh you a reason of the hope that is in you with meekness and fear: Having a good conscience; that, whereas they speak evil of you, as of evildoers, they may be ashamed that falsely accuse your good conversation in Christ" [1 Peter 3:15-16].

For another, there may be times when living peaceably means compromising with the world's values, or even condoning wickedness. At times like these, we have to stand firm, and pray for courage and wisdom to do the right thing for the sake of God's name.
1 NOVEMBER.part7: Let your light so shine before men, that they may see your good works, and glorify your Father which is in heaven. - Matthew 5:16

2 NOVEMBER.part4: Dearly beloved, avenge not yourselves, but rather give place unto wrath: for it is written, Vengeance is mine; I will repay, saith the Lord.
2 NOVEMBER.part5:
We have looked previously at some verses about not avenging ourselves. In verse 14, we were told to bless our persecutors. In verse 17, we were exhorted to not recompense evil for evil. We also considered reasons like God blessing those who suffer for His name, breaking the vicious cycle of evil and hate, following the steps of our Lord to do what is right, good, and beautiful. Today, we are given another important reason: Vengeance belongs to the Lord.

God is sovereign and just. He knows the injustices we have suffered, especially those endured for His name. This should give us peace in times of affliction. Psalm 37:1-5 assures us, "Fret not thyself because of evildoers, neither be thou envious against the workers of iniquity. For they shall soon be cut down like the grass, and wither as the green herb. Trust in the LORD, and do good; so shalt thou dwell in the land, and verily thou shalt be fed. Delight thyself also in the LORD: and he shall give thee the desires of thine heart. Commit thy way unto the LORD; trust also in him; and he shall bring it to pass." We are to trust God, delight in Him, and commit everything in His hands. Hold to what is right and wait upon Him to bring His will to pass.

Think about it: If we were to take things into our own hands, we are losing faith in our God who will exact justice in His own good time. This charge should be a reminder for all who fear the Lord and cause us to leave everything in the good hands of our all-knowing and all-powerful God.
2 NOVEMBER.part7: See that none render evil for evil unto any man; but ever follow that which is good, both among yourselves, and to all men. - 1 Thessalonians 5:15

3 NOVEMBER.part4: Therefore if thine enemy hunger, feed him; if he thirst, give him drink: for in so doing thou shalt heap coals of fire on his head. Be not overcome of evil, but overcome evil with good.
3 NOVEMBER.part5:
Romans 12:17, 18 and 21 tell us three possible responses against evil. Verse 17 reminds us "the sinner's approach", which is recompensing evil for evil. This is the reaction deemed natural by the world.

Verse 18 offers "the passive approach" of striving to live peaceably with others, choosing to overlook the trespasses of people against us. Verse 21, on the other hand, gives a more positive approach, which can be described as "the active approach", which is to overcome evil with good.

Overcoming evil with good does not mean we smile foolishly at people who hit us or give more to those who rob us. Rather, it means when the opportunity comes for us to do good to a person who has previously done us evil, we should choose to do it. From the first two approaches and eventually to the third option, we can see the growth of a Christian as he struggles with evil, and he finally overcomes it, both the evil without and the sin within.

The effect of this is described as heaping coals of fire on the offender's head. Proverbs 25:21-22 similarly says: "If thine enemy be hungry, give him bread to eat; and if he be thirsty, give him water to drink: For thou shalt heap coals of fire upon his head, and the LORD shall reward thee." This may refer to an Egyptian custom of carrying a pan of burning coals on one's head as a sign of contrition or to bring about a change of heart. Thus, returning good for evil can hasten an offender to repent of his ways. To an unbeliever, to "overcome evil with good" characterises a child of God. To a believer, it will help win back a brother from his sinful ways.
3 NOVEMBER.part7: For if ye love them which love you, what reward have ye? do not even the publicans the same? - Matthew 5:46

4 NOVEMBER.part4: Let every soul be subject unto the higher powers. For there is no power but of God: the powers that be are ordained of God.
4 NOVEMBER.part5:
Paul says, "Let every soul be subject unto the higher powers." The command is that every person, Christian or not, Jewish or Gentile, should be subject to their governing authorities. This is clearly spelt out in Titus 3:1; "Subject to principalities and powers, to obey magistrates".

Peter elaborates on this submission further in 1 Peter 2:13, where one is to be subject "to every ordinance of man for the Lord's sake: whether it be to the king, as supreme". Every person is required to be subject to those who are in authority by the will of God.

Paul then reiterates "For there is no power but of God: the powers that be are ordained of God." The reason we submit to the governing authorities is because there is no authority apart from God, and He has instituted the authorities that exist. It is God's will to govern the world through human civil authorities.

We must submit to the civil authorities, in deed and heart, because without them there can be no order, security, or progress in society. Rebelling against God-ordained authorities constitutes rebellion against God. Such rebels we are told, will be punished by Him. Government exists to preserve law and order, any Christian who opposes His government by force will receive just retribution from the governing authority. If the government is established, and if its decisions are not a manifest violation of God's laws, then we are to submit.
4 NOVEMBER.part7: Respect for authority brings glory to God.

5 NOVEMBER.part4: For he is the minister of God to thee for good. But if thou do that which is evil, be afraid; for he beareth not the sword in vain: for he is the minister of God, a revenger to execute wrath upon him that doeth evil.
5 NOVEMBER.part5:
Civil government according to the teaching of scripture is a divine institution. "There is no power but of God: the powers that be are ordained of God." [v. 1] This is not to be understood as meaning that every individual who is ordained by God is a blessing and an instrument for good. That would make the Divine Being directly responsible for ordaining the tyrants and their evil acts of despotism and oppression. Rather, it means that government is an ordinance of God, and He has ordained or appointed that there should be authority and rulers. And every ruler on his throne has been put into power according to God's sovereign will and purposes [Daniel 2:21].

According to Paul, the government was instituted by God to serve two specific functions which are described in Romans 13:3-4. It is designed by God to check evil and promote good. These are the reasons God established government and so long as a government is rewarding moral good and restraining moral evil, it is acting as God's servant and to be obeyed.

In the latter part of verse 4, Paul gives the grounds for the state's sword-bearing powers. "For he beareth not the sword in vain." God has given the government the power of life and death over her subjects to maintain order. Therefore, one should hold the government's authority in healthy respect or face its consequences.
5 NOVEMBER.part7: Submit yourselves to every ordinance for the Lord's sake: whether it be the king as supreme. - 1 Peter 2:13

6 NOVEMBER.part4: Wherefore ye must needs be subject, not only for wrath, but also for conscience sake.
6 NOVEMBER.part5:
Let every soul be subject unto higher powers. Such is Paul's instruction to Christians living under their heathen government, and he adds in verse 5, that we must "be subject, not only for wrath, but also for conscience sake".

There are two reasons to be in subjection: fear of punishment and conscience before God, who has ordained the government. "Wrath" denotes judicial punishment. To defy the government is to invite death or suffer judgment and penalties such as imprisonment. We should be subject to our government not only because we fear punishment but also because we fear God, who knows our hearts.

Christians are to be loyal to the government under which they live. They are to obey the laws and do nothing that would bring the laws into contempt. We must do, not by compulsion but freely, not for fear of the penalties which disobedience might incur but for conscience's sake.

Paying taxes is part of submission. In Romans 13:6-7, we are called to support the government, "For this cause pay ye tribute also: for they are God's ministers, attending continually upon this very thing." The "very thing" speaks of the responsibility of ruling, the service of leading people, protecting them, collecting taxes. To defend the country, maintain law and order, and provide service for the citizens, the government has the legitimate right to collect taxes.

Let us pay the taxes required. Have respect for those who collect our taxes because it is right and it pleases God. Instead of grumbling, whisper a prayer of thanksgiving and pray for the government to utilize our tax money appropriately and wisely. Take heart that you are being obedient to God's will.
6 NOVEMBER.part7: Lord, help us fulfil our responsibility to our government as good citizens.

7 NOVEMBER.part4: Owe no man any thing, but to love one another: for he that loveth another hath fulfilled the law.
7 NOVEMBER.part5:
Paul instructed the Christians to submit to civil government and those in authority v. 1-5. The authorities are God's servants governing the country and whatever taxes are owed must be paid, so too respect and honour v. 6-7.

Apart from taxes that must be paid to the government, Christians also render respect and honour to many categories of people, for example, kings [1 Peter 2:13-17]; church officers [1 Timothy 5:17; Hebrews 13:17]; parents [Exodus 20:12]; older persons [Leviticus 19:32] and most of all, God [1 Timothy 6:16; John 5:22-23] whom we worship and honour.

God's Word neither forbids borrowing nor lending money [Matthew 5:42], but we are not to be predatory and charge unreasonably high-interest rates when lending to the poor [Exodus 22:25; Psalm 15:5]. The Lord will recompense this kind deed to the poor [Proverbs 19:17]. Even so, Christians are never justified in going into debt unnecessarily. We should exercise godly wisdom in financial planning so that all debts are repaid in full on time so we owe no one anything.

Paul then declares that Christians have another debt to pay. They have a constant obligation to love one another in obedience to the Lord Jesus' command [John 13:34]. It is a perpetual debt that we need to continually pay yet never fully pay up. We thank the Lord that out of the abundance of His richness, love, and grace, He enables us to make this daily payment of love to one another with joy. Truly by loving one another, we fulfil the law.
7 NOVEMBER.part7: Then saith he unto them, Render therefore unto Caesar the things which are Caesar's; and unto God the things that are God's. - Matthew 22:21

8 NOVEMBER.part4: For this, Thou shalt not commit adultery, Thou shalt not kill, Thou shalt not steal, Thou shalt not bear false witness, Thou shalt not covet; and if there be any other commandment, it is briefly comprehended in this saying, namely, Thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyself.
8 NOVEMBER.part5:
The Mosaic Law was given to the Israelites by God through Moses. The first four consist of commandments in regard to the Israelites' relationship with God, and the following six in regard to their relationship with man.

When the Pharisees tempted Jesus, asking Him, "Which is the great commandment in the Law?" Jesus answered that the first great commandment was "Thou shalt love the Lord thy God with all thy heart, and with all thy soul, and with all thy mind" and the second great commandment was "Thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyself " [Matthew 22:37-39]. While Jesus spoke of the first table (love for God) and the second table (love for man) Paul here speaks only of the love for fellow men, and in its context how Christians are to act towards one another. If "you love your neighbour," you shall do the following:

You shall not commit adultery but preserve the sacredness of the marriage-bond just as Joseph resisted the advances of Potiphar's wife [Genesis 39:8-9; Matthew 5:27-28]. You shall not murder nor harm him with thought, word or deed [Matthew 5:21-22] but shall help to keep preserve the life of your neighbour. You shall not steal nor cheat in your dealings with others. You will protect your neighbour's possessions and be content with what you have [1 Timothy 6:6]. You shall not covet but rejoice in the fact that your neighbours' possessions are his [Hebrews 13:5].

Since we love ourselves despite our own faults, we are to love our neighbour too no matter how unlikeable he may be. Hence, "You shall love your neighbour as yourself."
8 NOVEMBER.part7: Be ye holy; for I am holy. - 1 Peter 1:16

9 NOVEMBER.part4: Love worketh no ill to his neighbour: therefore love is the fulfilling of the law.
9 NOVEMBER.part5:
Love worketh no ill to his neighbour, is a figure of speech called "litotes". It is a negative expression that conveys a strong affirmative. The verse is thus interpreted as "Love greatly benefits the neighbour". As Paul told the Galatians, "As we have therefore opportunity, let us do good unto all men, especially unto them who are of the household of faith" [Galatians 6:10]. The key word in both great commandments is love [Matthew 22:37-39], and only love can fulfil the law.

Because God is our Creator and Redeemer, the God of love who first loved us, we in return are to love Him and our fellowmen as He commanded. Love is the first named fruit of the Spirit. We are to love with a godly righteous love that is pure and sincere, abhorring evil, cleaving to that which is good, with brotherly affection for one another, honouring and preferring one another [Romans 12:9-10]. Love begins with a heart of compassion and forgiveness [Ephesians 4:32]. It is characterized by humility, gentleness, patience, and forbearance [Ephesians 4:2; 1 Corinthians 13:4-7].

Godly love moves us to live godly lives, bearing a good testimony for the Lord, having compassion for the lost by bringing the Gospel to them and praying for their salvation "by pureness, by knowledge, by longsuffering, by kindness, by the Holy Ghost, by love unfeigned, By the word of truth, by the power of God, by the armour of righteousness on the right hand and on the left" [2 Corinthians 6:6-7]. God's Word clearly exhorts us to love our neighbour. Are you obeying His command?
9 NOVEMBER.part7: Heavenly Father, teach me to love others even as Thou hast first loved me.

10 NOVEMBER.part4: And that, knowing the time, that now it is high time to awake out of sleep: for now is our salvation nearer than when we believed.
10 NOVEMBER.part5:
This is a wake-up call for us. The Apostle Paul summons us to wake up from our spiritual slumber, to live righteously, to actively repay the debt of loving one another [v. 8], and to love our neighbour as ourselves [v. 9]. He also encourages the brethren to accept those who are weak in faith [Romans 14:1], to be Christ-like, to love others [Romans 15:5], and to be united with one heart to glorify God.

Why did Paul inject a sense of urgency? The reason is that we do not have much time as the day of Christ's return is imminent. The signs are clearly visible. We witness wars and rumours of wars, threats of nuclear missile attacks, heightened social and geo-political tensions, pandemics, increasing frequency and intensity of earthquakes, floods, and other natural and man-made disasters. These are the signs that judgment day is near and we should be well prepared.

Jesus also warns us in Matthew 7:21-23 that not everyone who calls him "Lord, Lord" will enter His heavenly kingdom. Only those who do the will of the Father will be recognized by Him and granted entrance there. The will of the Lord is for us to cultivate an intimate relationship with Him, to be obedient in following God's Word, and to love and serve one another.

Let us take heed. Let us live harmoniously and peacefully with one other, live sacrificially for God and live by faith in Christ. Be prepared at all times to witness for our Lord, share the Gospel and lead others to believe in Jesus Christ as their personal saviour.
10 NOVEMBER.part7: O Lord, may I wake up everyday knowing that thy salvation is near and put on the armour of light to live righteously. I ask that You will give me faith, love and strength in You, to be your witness and live a life that glorifies your name. Amen.

11 NOVEMBER.part4: The night is far spent, the day is at hand: let us therefore cast off the works of darkness, and let us put on the armour of light.
11 NOVEMBER.part5:
Verse 12 is even more alarming than the preceding verse. Paul considers that the evil time is almost over. The night refers to this current corrupted age in a wicked and sinful world. The day points to the second coming of Christ, which is almost here. If we are wise and realize the times in which we live, we will do what is necessary and right.

As God's children, we thank Him for delivering us from the present evil age [Galatians 1:4]. We are part of a world ruled by Satan, full of temptation, deceptions, and disappointments. But we have been redeemed by the precious blood of Jesus Christ, gained the victory through faith in Christ, and we are no longer enslaved to the wicked ways of the world.

Paul explains it well in 1 Corinthians 7:29. Our time is short. He urges us to make the most of it. We should have the sense of urgency to tell others the Good News. Do we use the talents and opportunities given by the Lord to serve others? We must put on our spiritual armour and be careful to live a consecrated life. "See then that ye walk circumspectly, not as fools, but as wise, redeeming the time, because the days are evil" [Ephesians 5:15-16]. The world we live in is evil, and we must be vigilant. It is important to stay close to the Lord, arming ourselves with wisdom from above, and protecting ourselves with God's presence so that we can walk the narrow path of righteousness.
11 NOVEMBER.part7: What do I need to do in order to be approved when I meet Jesus Christ? Will I hear Jesus saying: "Well done, good and faithful servant; thou hast been faithful over a few things, I will make thee ruler over many things: enter thou into the joy of thy lord." - Matthew 25:23.
