12 NOVEMBER.part4: Let us walk honestly, as in the day; not in rioting and drunkenness, not in chambering and wantonness, not in strife and envying.
12 NOVEMBER.part5:
As children of light, we should not be indulging in sleep and sloth. We are to be sober and watchful, alert, and self-controlled. We are to refrain from sinful acts, from participating in the darkness of wild parties and drunkenness, from living in sexual promiscuity and immorality, or in quarreling and jealousy. We are to put on faith and love as our breastplate, and the hope of salvation as our helmet [1 Thessalonians 5:4-8].

The moral standards today are in decline. As God's people, we go with the flow and lower our standards; rather we are to live a holy life in accordance with God's Word. We should draw close to the Lord every day through prayer and Bible study. We must devote ourselves to the Lord by denying our own will and not indulging our flesh. By the help of God, we must not give in to temptation which will lead to disastrous outcomes. If we really put God above self, let the Holy Spirit guide our thoughts, words, and actions. If Christ is the Master of our life, we will be filled with God's peace and love. It will overflow to others and show our love for them, instead of strife, jealousy, and hatred.

When we arise in the morning, commit to conducting ourselves in a manner that will honour the Lord. Speak, behave, and think like Christ. Walk honestly and properly by involving God in every aspect of our lives. We need to walk in the Spirit, and we will not fulfil the lust of the flesh [read Galatians 5:16-18].
12 NOVEMBER.part7: And the very God of peace sanctify you wholly; and I pray God your whole spirit and soul and body be preserved blameless unto the coming of our Lord Jesus Christ. - 1 Thessalonians 5:23.

13 NOVEMBER.part4: But put ye on the Lord Jesus Christ, and make not provision for the flesh, to fulfil the lusts thereof.
13 NOVEMBER.part5:
The man in his natural state will manifest all manner of sinful attitudes and behaviour like dishonesty, pride, greed, hatred, idolatry, drunkenness, and immorality, to name a few. When a person has come to saving faith, we put on the Lord Jesus Christ because "he hath clothed me with the garments of salvation, he hath covered me with the robe of righteousness" [Isaiah 61:10].

Putting on the Lord Jesus also means continuous spiritual growth after conversion. This process of sanctification is the work of the Holy Spirit to transform us to be more and more Christ-like. We desire to obey God and please Him in our thoughts and deeds. While we are in our mortal bodies, the desire to sin surfaces from time to time. If we succumb to that desire, it shows that sin still has a powerful grip on us.

The Apostle Paul urges us to put down the desire to please ourselves. To "make not provision for the flesh" means that we are not to give forethought or plan how we can satisfy and fulfil the desires and lusts of our hearts. The more thought we give to sin, the more space it has to grow, the more it will come to fruition. Instead, we are to fill our minds with the Word of God which leads us toward righteousness and obedience [Psalm 119:9, 11]. Reading, meditating and memorising God's Word will keep us from sinning against God. May He help us to give time and attention to understanding His Word so we can be sanctified and kept from sin.
13 NOVEMBER.part7: This I say then, walk in the Spirit, and ye shall not fulfil the lust of the flesh. - Galatians 5:16

14 NOVEMBER.part4: Him that is weak in the faith receive ye, but not to doubtful disputations.
14 NOVEMBER.part5:
Here, the Apostle Paul turns his attention to the attitude that Christians should adopt towards one another in matters where God's Word is silent - things that are morally neutral.

Strong believers - those who are more mature in the faith - understand and enjoy freedom in Christ. Weak believers - new believers and those who are spiritually immature - remain constrained by religious or cultural taboos and practices that were ingrained before their salvation.

The strong believer may view his weaker brother as rigid for binding himself to unnecessary rules. As long as no saving merit is ascribed to such practices, these self-imposed restrictions can be tolerated. The weak believer may regard the strong believer as being ill-disciplined and unwilling to subject his body and mind to the Spirit's control. Such differences in opinions can easily lead to tension among believers.

Just as God receives all believers who place their faith in Jesus to save them, strong and weak Christians must accept one another with the view that all are children of our Lord Jesus. Unity among believers is of greater importance than to debate and disagree over such issues.

Paul exhorts the strong believers to receive the weaker ones with love, patience, and forbearance because the stronger believers are in a better position to help the weak. Not all believers grow to full maturity at the same rate, but Paul does not want to reduce the whole church to the level of the weak. Spiritually weaker believers need the fellowship of the stronger believers to be strengthened in their faith and shielded from harm. May God help us to support one another in our spiritual walk so all may grow in faith and serve God to His glory.
14 NOVEMBER.part7: Beloved, if God so loved us, we ought also to love one another. - 1 John 4:11

15 NOVEMBER.part4: Let not him that eateth despise him that eateth not; and let not him which eateth not judge him that eateth: for God hath received him.
15 NOVEMBER.part5:
God accepts us because the righteousness of our Lord Jesus is imputed onto us through His death on the cross to pay for our sins. To ask for more would be denying the Gospel and operating on the basis of salvation by works. The stronger believer has, by God's grace, gained an insight into the meaning of Christ's death for daily living. Therefore, he is able to eat meat. The weaker brother, with lesser understanding and a tender conscience, eats only vegetables.

Paul said it was wrong for believers to treat one another with contempt on account of their differing opinions. Our Lord Jesus taught that it is not what we eat that defiles us, rather sin comes from the evil in our heart [Mark 7:15-23].

Every Christian, being God's servant, is answerable to Him alone. Our assessment of other believers does not affect their standing before Him because only God's judgment matters v. 10. Paul assures us that the our Lord Jesus will sustain every one of His servants so they can bring Him honour and glory v. 4. There is no condemnation because we are in Christ, and nothing can separate us from the love of God. [Romans 8:1, 38-39] Therefore, let us not fault one another over insignificant issues but seek God's wisdom to strengthen one another in the faith. The more mature in faith among us should uphold our less mature brethren in prayer, and encourage them to grow closer to God in their spiritual walk.
15 NOVEMBER.part7: Wherefore he is able also to save them to the uttermost that come unto God by him, seeing he ever liveth to make intercession for them. - Hebrews 7:25

16 NOVEMBER.part4: He that regardeth the day, regardeth it unto the Lord; and he that regardeth not the day, to the Lord he doth not regard it. He that eateth, eateth to the Lord, for he giveth God thanks; and he that eateth not, to the Lord he eateth not, and giveth God thanks.
16 NOVEMBER.part5:
Some Christians regarded certain days as special while others did not. Some Christians adhered to special diets while others ate all types of food. They had different ideas but the same goal of pleasing God. Some Christians of each persuasion may have thought themselves more spiritual and those belonging to the opposite camp as carnal. Paul sought to rid the believers of such erroneous and divisive notions.

In matters not expressly spoken of in God's Word, believers should study scripture to extract the biblical principles that will guide their actions. Every believer should be a responsible and thinking Christian who works through these matters themselves so that they come to a deeper understanding of how to please God. This will ensure that our hearts and minds are fully convinced as to how to obey God. We will then be able to follow our conscience which represents what we believe is right. Yet, we should avoid imposing our convictions on other believers lest it causes them to go against their conscience.

Being "fully persuaded in his own mind" implies that we think only of pleasing the Lord in our choices and cast no reflection on others because we know they are also earnestly striving to please God in their choices. In other words, we examine ourselves carefully as we make choices in our daily lives. Are we serving God with our talents and resources in what we do? Do our choices truly glorify God's name? Are we able to enjoy the activity we are engaging in and give thanks unto the Lord for it?
16 NOVEMBER.part7: Let no man therefore judge you in meat, or in drink, or in respect of an holyday, or of the new moon, or of the sabbath days: Which are a shadow of things to come; but the body is of Christ. - Colossians 2:16-17

17 NOVEMBER.part4: For whether we live, we live unto the Lord; and whether we die, we die unto the Lord: whether we live therefore, or die, we are the Lord's.
17 NOVEMBER.part5:
We live unto the Lord. We also die unto the Lord. We are the Lord's. The Lordship of Christ is without doubt one of the great themes of the New Testament. The word "Lord" (Gk: kurios), which means "master," appears over 700 times. In Romans 14, kurios is used ten times in five verses v. 6, 8, 9, 11, and 14.

The Apostle Paul uses the title for Jesus, indicating that our Saviour is also our Lord; that there is no salvation apart from Lordship. The title, however, is not simply a point of doctrine. Our Lord Jesus Himself warns that "not every one that saith unto me, Lord, Lord, shall enter into the kingdom of heaven; but he that doeth the will of my Father which is in heaven" [Matthew 7:21].

In Romans 14:8, Paul is emphasising that Christ is the centre of everything from beginning to end. At the very heart of our coming to Christ is surrendering our lives to Him, and Christcenteredness is a heart issue and an issue of the heart. Paul's reasoning is simple, if we live, is only because God sustains us - it is "in him we live, and move, and have our being" [Acts 17:28]. If we are saved, it is because He has redeemed us with His own precious blood [1 Peter 1:18-19]. And when we die, it is Christ calling us home unto Himself.

So, whether we live or die, we are fully persuaded, that neither death, nor life, nor angels, nor principalities, nor powers, nor things present, nor things to come, nor height, nor depth, nor any other creature, shall be able to separate us from the love of God, which is in Christ Jesus our Lord [Romans 8:38-39].
17 NOVEMBER.part7: For to me to live is Christ, and to die is gain. - Philippians 1:21

18 NOVEMBER.part4: For to this end Christ both died, and rose, and revived, that he might be Lord both of the dead and living.
18 NOVEMBER.part5:
The first man, Adam, opened the door of death to his posterity when he ate the forbidden fruit (of death) after his wife Eve was deceived into taking it by the evil one [1 Timothy 2:14]. He could not die for her, but he died with her at that moment. He could not restore her to her unfallen state, but he would go down with her in her fallen state.

The last Adam [1 Corinthians 15:45] came and opened the door of eternal life to all His beloved ones, His chosen bride. He resisted and overcame the temptations of the Devil. He lived a sinless life and became the perfect sacrifice for His bride by dying for her. His love for her was strong as death. He died that she might live and rose again for her justification.

O beloved child of God, Christ died to take away your sins; He died in your place to save you from eternal damnation, a Christless eternity, where there is utter darkness, weeping and gnashing of teeth. "Blessed and holy is he that hath part in the first resurrection: on such the second death hath no power" [Revelation 20:6a].

The death of Christ was the death of Death, and the hymnwriter succinctly and beautifully captures the wonders of this atoning death of Christ on the cross - "Who died, eternal life to bring, and lives that death may die."  Crown Him the Lord of life, Who triumphed o'er the grave, And rose victorious in the strife For those He came to save; His glories now we sing Who died, and rose on high, Who died, eternal life to bring, And lives that death may die.
18 NOVEMBER.part7:
Crown Him the Lord of life
Who triumphed o'er the grave
And rose victorious in the strife,
For those He came to save;
His glories now we sing,
Who died, and rose on high
Who died, eternal life to bring
And lives that death may die.

19 NOVEMBER.part4: So then every one of us shall give account of himself to God.
19 NOVEMBER.part5:
There is a day of reckoning when every one of us shall, inevitably and certainly, stand before God to give account of ourselves to Him. Apostle Paul in his 2nd letter to the Corinthians speaks of the same thing [2 Corinthians 5:10]. The wise king Solomon and Preacher summed up the conclusion of the whole matter: "Fear God, and keep his commandments: for this is the whole duty of man. For God shall bring every work into judgment, with every secret thing, whether it be good, or whether it be evil" [Ecclesiastes 12:13-4].

Even our words will be judged. Our Lord said that "every idle word that men shall speak, they shall give account thereof in the day of judgment. For by thy words thou shalt be justified, and by thy words thou shalt be condemned" [Matthew 12:36-37].

The parable in Matthew 25:14-29 gives us a glimpse of how we will be giving account of the talents given to us while we are on earth. God will reward the Christian who is faithful and fruitful. And He will render judgment on the idle and self-centered man.

This is a sobering thought, and we ought to reflect and repent while there is time and opportunity. Our life, every word, thought and action, will have to be accounted for on judgment day.

The great Puritan, John Bunyan, gave us his hearty counsel before finally standing at the judgment seat of God "Thus, every morning and evening, make up thy accounts with the Almighty God, and thy reckonings will be the less at last."
19 NOVEMBER.part7: The Christian is justified by his faith in Christ and judged by his works for Christ.

20 NOVEMBER.part4: Let us not therefore judge one another any more: but judge this rather, that no man put a stumblingblock or an occasion to fall in his brother's way.
20 NOVEMBER.part5:
The Apostle Paul has in the preceding verse brought believer and unbelievers before the judgment bar of Christ. Every one of us has to give an account of ourselves before the Righteous Judge. With this sobering thought, he now brings them back to the church with instructions to put away the censorious and judgmental spirit that is common among them - a spirit that is contrary to personal holiness and practical godliness, and it is unhealthy for the church.

The church consists of believers of different maturity, talents, and gifts, serving in different offices and ministries. Theological knowledge is indispensable to Christian growth, but it can puff up a person [1 Corinthians 8:1b]. Superior biblical knowledge can be mistaken for spiritual maturity and can lead one to regard oneself better than others. Thinking that he knows more, he starts to pick on others' weaknesses and passes judgment on those he deems lesser or who disagree with his convictions. It is not uncommon to have believers among us developing such undesirable traits, failing to recognise that the church consists of believers who are all imperfect and still growing spiritually. Paul warns that "knowledge puffeth up, but charity edifieth. [1 Corinthians 8:1b] We will do well to take to heart the wisdom of the old adage that says: In essentials, unity. In non-essentials, liberty. But in all things, charity.

Be mindful of the weak and young in faith lest by our unguarded zeal, we cause them to stumble. The Lord will not hold us guiltless for He said, "But whoso shall offend one of these little ones which believe in me, it were better for him that a millstone were hanged about his neck, and that he were drowned in the depth of the sea" [Matthew 18:6].
20 NOVEMBER.part7: An ounce of love is worth a pond of knowledge. - John Wesley.

21 NOVEMBER.part4: I know, and am persuaded by the Lord Jesus, that there is nothing unclean of itself: but to him that esteemeth any thing to be unclean, to him it is unclean.
21 NOVEMBER.part5:
The imperfect church on earth can only be perfected in heaven. On this side of eternity, the imperfections of the church will be manifested. Even necessities of life can be an issue to be contended upon. Paul now addresses that part of Christian practice which is issues-oriented. He makes explicitly clear that there is nothing unclean of itself, for every creature of God is good, and nothing to be refused, if it be received with thanksgiving: for it is sanctified by the word of God and prayer [1 Timothy 4:4]. Yet Paul did not impose his apostolic authority; instead he urged tolerance with brotherly love. "The servant of the Lord must not strive; but be gentle unto all men, apt to teach, patient" [2 Timothy 2:24].

Notwithstanding, the food that is offered in sacrifice unto idols, we are to abstain though an idol is nothing in the world. And if the Gentiles made it known that the food had been offered to idols, believers must certainly abstain [1 Corinthians 10:28].

Matthew Henry puts it this way, "Those who are strict in restraining their own liberty yet ought not to impose those restraints upon the liberty of others, nor to judge of them accordingly. We must not make ourselves the standard to measure others by. A good man will deny himself that liberty which he will not deny another."

The key lesson here is to preserve the unity of the Spirit, maintain peace and harmony within the church. If we differ in things non-essential, we must learn to agree to disagree and live peaceably among ourselves, for how good and how pleasant it is for the brethren to dwell together in unity.
21 NOVEMBER.part7: That they all may be one; as thou, Father, art in me, and I in thee, that they also may be one in us: that the world may believe that thou hast sent me. - John 17:21.

22 NOVEMBER.part4: Let not then your good be evil spoken of:
22 NOVEMBER.part5:
Christians are no longer under the Old Covenant and the need to distinguish between unclean and clean foods or circumcision and uncircumcision. All things are lawful [1 Corinthians 10:23]. While Christians are freed from ceremonial law [Galatians 3:23-25], some may have difficulty living with such freedom.

For Paul's audience, some Jewish Christians weaker in faith still observed old Jewish dietary laws. Other Christians stronger in faith embraced Christian liberty and ate any food they pleased. Paul warns stronger Christians not to flaunt their Christian liberty in a way that reflects badly on Christianity. Our freedom is good - but we should not abuse our freedom in Christ to risk stumbling a weaker brother who still believes some things are wrong.

Paul's warning is also to weaker Christians and a reminder they ought not to criticise those who feel that they are free to eat anything. In relation to foods, dress, rites, and ceremonies in the church, we may feel that our personal convictions are the only right ones. Obstinate adherence to these may nevertheless give rise to slanderous talk, contention, bitter discussions, and evil reports. Such conduct contradicts Christ's love.

Whether in exercising Christian liberty or in how we think we ought to live, let us do all things in a manner, spirit, and time that is productive of the greatest good. May we put aside private, unimportant personal indulgences and prize the good of peace with our brothers and sisters in Christ.
22 NOVEMBER.part7:
Blest be the tie that bind
our hearts in Christian love;
the fellowship of kindred minds
is like to that above.

23 NOVEMBER.part4: For the kingdom of God is not meat and drink; but righteousness, and peace, and joy in the Holy Ghost. For he that in these things serveth Christ is acceptable to God, and approved of men.
23 NOVEMBER.part5:
The kingdom of God is not found in meticulously eating and drinking the right things. It is also not found in indulging ourselves to eat and drink every and anything we like. God's kingdom is neither following a set of religious observances. Nor is it throwing away all order and simply living as we please.

The kingdom of God is the realm of God's rule, which is present and seen in whatever God does in the lives of Christians and their relationships with God and others. It comprises three great attributes which are in essence unselfish.

There is righteousness, found in those who by God's grace open their hearts to receive Christ and are justified by the merit of His death. Because of our new standing before God, we are to be righteous in our dealings with God and men.

There is peace with God because our relationship with Him is right. Because we have peace with Him, we are to pursue peace with others.

There is the overflowing joy of being reconciled with God. Because of this joy, we are to share our joy with others too. Paul tells us that the kingdom of God is being in a right relationship with God and with others. Serving Christ by focusing on righteousness, peace, and joy in the Holy Spirit is pleasing to God. Instead of speaking ill of us, the world will acknowledge that we are genuine.
23 NOVEMBER.part7:
Living for Jesus, a life that is true,
Striving to please Him in all that I do;
Yielding allegiance, glad-hearted and free,
This is the pathway of blessing for me.

24 NOVEMBER.part4: Let us therefore follow after the things which make for peace, and things wherewith one may edify another.
24 NOVEMBER.part5:
Paul exhorts the church at Rome to lay aside their contentions and channel their time and energy to things that build harmony and love within the body of Christ. We too should do everything we can to build up fellow Christians by what we say or do and not discourage them.

To make way for peace we must first put aside things that create strife. Be careful especially of the words we say, which may have far-reaching consequences [James 3:5], and resist the urge for slander and gossip. Be swift to hear, slow to speak, and slow to wrath [James 1:19]. Consider carefully whether what we say is corrupting or helpful in building others up and appropriate for the occasion [Ephesians 4:29].

Whether strong or weak, we are to diligently keep the unity of the Spirit in the bond of peace [Ephesians 4:3]. Keeping the peace is not simply being silent and agreeable. Building up others requires us to be present and genuine, or else we become like those whom Jeremiah described as saying peace, peace, when there is no peace [Jeremiah 6:14].

We then ought to edify and help each other along the spiritual road we are travelling. Building each other up requires the participation of all members of the church - encouraging each other and holding one another accountable helps each of us become more Christ-like.
24 NOVEMBER.part7: What are you doing to build up the body of Christ today?

25 NOVEMBER.part4: For meat destroy not the work of God. All things indeed are pure; but it is evil for that man who eateth with offence. It is good neither to eat flesh, nor to drink wine, nor any thing whereby thy brother stumbleth, or is offended, or is made weak.
25 NOVEMBER.part5:
Paul is likely addressing the strong Christian when he says what we eat does not destroy the work of God. Paul also assures the strong Christian that there is nothing impure in food itself. However, Paul emphasises that the strong who have no convictions against eating such food fall into sin when others stumble and fall away from Christ upon observing how they behave. It is tragic to think that by our obstinate attachment to our own opinions, we may lead a brother to confusion and sin.

Even if all things are lawful, not everything is expedient and not everything builds others up [1 Corinthians 10:23-24]. Our freedom in Christ should never mean we celebrate it at the expense of others.

It is not good for us to do anything that causes a brother in Christ to be confused, or to feel so lacking that he is tempted to drop his profession of faith or become shaken in his spiritual walk. We may be rightly entitled to exercise our Christian liberty but if we confuse or cause our brothers to stumble over trivial matters out of a desire to indulge ourselves because we are indifferent to their spiritual state, we are not acting in love [Romans 13:10]. What we do and say can prompt a person to be led closer to Christ or drive them away. We should be aware of what we do, because others are watching us [Matthew 5:16].
25 NOVEMBER.part7:
Let me be a little meeker,
With the brother that is weaker.
Let me think more of my neighbor,
And a little less of me.

26 NOVEMBER.part4: Hast thou faith? have it to thyself before God. Happy is he that condemneth not himself in that thing which he alloweth.
26 NOVEMBER.part5:
Are you fully persuaded in your mind that something you are doing is right? Perhaps we think that something should be done a certain way. Or we may think that Christian liberty means there is no right or wrong way for certain things to be done.

Paul implies that while we need not surrender our convictions just because others are convicted otherwise, we should keep our convictions between ourselves and God, instead of raising them to dictate how others should live. Paul tells us we are happy indeed if we have a clear conscience in our opinions and conduct. We are blessed if we have strong faith and our consciences are not enslaved by laws and rules which concern matters of lesser importance, such as what we eat or drink.

Conversely, some of us may indulge in practices that our consciences condemn, or we are privately uneasy about. The way to be happy is to have a clear conscience in what we do. If we have doubts about a course of conduct, we should at once abandon it, but if our heart condemns us not, we have confidence toward God [1 John 3:21]. Ultimately, each of us are accountable to God [v. 10-12].

May we have a clear conscience before God so we may boldly approach His throne and find grace [Hebrews 4:16].
26 NOVEMBER.part7: Are my convictions pleasing to God, and edifying to my brother? Is there anything in my life that I do not have a clear conscience about and why am I continuing to do it?

27 NOVEMBER.part4: And he that doubteth is damned if he eat, because he eateth not of faith: for whatsoever is not of faith is sin.
27 NOVEMBER.part5:
In contrast to the Christian who acts from conviction is the weak Christian who has doubts. The doubts arise from the fact they do not have a faith strong enough to believe they can now dispense with the ritual elements of the OT law. These doubters, Paul says, are condemned when they eat. This is not simply a subjective self-condemnation; as the reference to sin later in the verse makes clear when Paul refers to God's disapproval of such an act. Condemnation comes not because of the eating itself, but what earns God's condemnation is eating when one does not have the faith to believe it is right to do so.

Faith here is the conviction stemming from one's faith in Christ. Paul is not claiming that any act that does not arise out of a basic trust and dependency on Christ is sinful, true as that may be. What he here labels as sin is any act that does not match our sincerely held convictions about what our Christian faith allows us to do or not do. For the Christian, not a single decision and action can be good which he does not think he can justify on the grounds of his Christian conviction and his liberty before God in Christ.

For Paul, then, sin is not only a matter of outward behaviours, but also inward motives. A weak conscience with weak faith would be healthier if it were strong, but such maturation must come by persuasion regarding what is God's will, not by simply changing behaviour without regard for motives. By appealing to the larger principle that anything not from faith is sin, Paul also returns to his emphasis on faith as a relationship with God in contrast to mere rules and regulations.
27 NOVEMBER.part7: Dear God, please bring my conscience in line with the Word of God and into conformity to the mind of Christ.

28 NOVEMBER.part4: We then that are strong ought to bear the infirmities of the weak, and not to please ourselves.
28 NOVEMBER.part5:
We are not individuals in isolation. We live in community; we live in relationships with other Christians in the brotherhood of the church. We are called to weep with those who weep, laugh with those who laugh, rejoice with those who rejoice and so on. The character of the Christian life is not one of selfishness or self-centeredness. We are to think about others and be concerned about them. Christians are called, in a spirit of charity, to be longsuffering and patient toward their fellowmen.

Those who pride themselves on their strength are obliged to use that to bear the weaknesses of those who are without strength in that matter. Paul is not urging us to bear with, just tolerate or put up with the weak but to sympathetically and empathetically enter into their circumstances, refrain from criticizing and judging them, and do what love toward them would require. Love requires the strong to willingly and lovingly assume for themselves the burden that their weaker brethren are carrying.

In the choice between enjoying our Christian liberty or forgoing it to avoid stumbling a fellow brother or sister, we are to choose the latter. It is with this mindset that others may be won more easily to a fuller faith, by surrounding them with an atmosphere of love rather than attacking them with a battery of criticism.
28 NOVEMBER.part7: May we parallel our Lord Jesus Christ in serving others and not with the priority of being served [Mark 10:45].

29 NOVEMBER.part4: Let every one of us please his neighbour for his good to edification.
29 NOVEMBER.part5:
The purpose of pleasing others is to seek the good of the weaker believer: his or her spiritual profit, in contrast to the spiritual harm that insensitive and selfish behaviour of the strong may cause. Paul defines this good more specifically in a second clause: edification or building up. This word takes us out of the narrowly individualistic realm. The spiritual profit to the weaker brother also profits the Christian community as a whole because their edification unifies the church. Building each other up in maturation of the faith ultimately brings brethren together in praise and in service. Therefore, our priority should be to help others instead of pleasing ourselves.

Christ offered the example of this readiness to forgo pleasing himself. Jesus stood between hostile parties as a mediator and absorbed unthinkable insult, slander and vicious attacks in doing so. None of the things Jesus was accused of were legitimate. He was without sin. Every time Jesus was criticized, every time Jesus was attacked, he was attacked unjustly. No one was ever justified in insulting Jesus. But he absorbed their hostility, anger and insults, offering a model of laying down one's desires to serve others.

By considering others before ourselves, we emulate our Lord and reflect more of His character. In this world where men are lovers of themselves, God calls us to love one another and to please others before self.
29 NOVEMBER.part7: Wherefore comfort yourselves together, and edify one another, even as also ye do. - 1 Thessalonians 5:11.

30 NOVEMBER.part4: For whatsoever things were written aforetime were written for our learning, that we through patience and comfort of the scriptures might have hope.
30 NOVEMBER.part5:
Sometimes we struggle to be disciplined in studying Scripture deeply. Although every Christian knows that studying God's Word is a must and our obligation to do, sometimes doing things that are our duty and obligation are not enjoyable. We would rather do things that help and benefit us directly. Yet God has given us the Bible not to be put on the shelf or to burden us but to teach us for our good!

The Old Testament, though no longer a source of direct moral imperative, continues to play a central role in helping Christians to have hope. In reading it and seeing its fulfilment in Christ and the church, the believer's hope is built up. And although Scripture demonstrates that God's way is never an easy way, in the end it is the only way to everything that makes life worthwhile in time and in eternity.

Secondly, Scripture gives us the great and precious promises of God. Because God is true and faithful in each and every promise to date, we can rest assured that God will remain faithful to the very end. Just as a child puts a candy in the mouth and savours it, so must the Christian dwell on the promises of God to enjoy it. In this way, Scripture gives to those who study it comfort in their sorrow and encouragement in their struggles.
30 NOVEMBER.part7: Thou art my hiding place and my shield: I hope in thy word. - Psalm 119:114.

1 DECEMBER.part4: That ye may with one mind and one mouth glorify God, even the Father of our Lord Jesus Christ.
1 DECEMBER.part5:
Paul offers a prayer and the recording of this prayer serves to exhort to its readers. Paul impresses unity upon them by using the second person plural (ye) to address the entire community. In this prayer, Paul urges Christians to think with a spirit of unity for the same thing; however, he is not praying these Christians all come to the same convictions about permissible foods. Rather, Paul is asking God to grant that they may remain united in their devotion and service to the Lord Jesus Christ.

In any community, there will be differences of opinion, and in any church there will be arguments and debate; but Christians who live in harmony have solved the problem of living together. They realize that the Christ who unites them is greater by far than the differences that may divide them. Divisions in the church over non-essential issues divert precious time and energy from her primary mission - the proclamation of the Gospel and the glorifying of God.

To achieve this goal of unity, we have to "be clothed with humility" [1 Peter 5:5]. Humility is the virtue everyone knows they need, but nobody wants. And when we think we have humility, it is a sure indication that we have lost it. Let us always look to Jesus, the greatest example of humility, who condescended to man and lived a life of obedience to the cross so that through Him we might be saved.
1 DECEMBER.part7: Dear God, humble me to serve others rather than myself, and that together we may glorify you with our mouths and our hands as your church. Amen.

2 DECEMBER.part4: Wherefore receive ye one another, as Christ also received us to the glory of God.
2 DECEMBER.part5:
To receive someone is to welcome them. It implies an active personal and willing acceptance of the person. There is certainly no animosity, no disinterest nor apathy such that we ignore the other. Merely surrendering to the notion of unity is insufficient. More than passively receiving, the idea conveyed is to "take to one's self ". It is a command by God. It must be a taking to one's self of the other person because we are of one mouth and one mind [v. 6] There are no differences spiritually because we are united and like-minded in our Lord Jesus Christ.

The pattern of taking into friendship and allowing access to one's life is the Lord Jesus Christ Himself. "And the Pharisees and scribes murmured, saying, This man receiveth sinners, and eateth with them." [Luke 15:2] "Take heed that ye despise not one of these little ones; for I say unto you, That in heaven their angels do always behold the face of my Father which is in heaven. For the Son of man is come to save that which was lost." [Matthew 18:10-11]

It is God who has given in order for the children of God to receive another into fellowship. God saves in Christ, converting sinners into saints, and then He brings them together, thereby adding them into a community of believers.

Christ the Lord and Saviour is our pattern by how He welcomed us into His saving arms. As the Lord has saved sinners and taken them to be His own, they too are to warmly accept each other to the glory of God the Father.
2 DECEMBER.part7: A new commandment I give unto you, That ye love one another; as I have loved you, that ye also love one another. - John 13:34

3 DECEMBER.part4: Now I say that Jesus Christ was a minister of the circumcision for the truth of God, to confirm the promises made unto the fathers:
3 DECEMBER.part5:
The Lord Jesus being a minister was a servant of God the Father, doing His will. He came to those of the circumcision (the Jews) and in so doing, established that all God had said is true. It confirmed that God is true and does not lie. It confirmed that God Himself is Truth, the objective standard by which all things are measured to be true or false. God made the promise to Abraham, the father of the nation of Israel:

"And I will make of thee a great nation, and I will bless thee, and make thy name great; and thou shalt be a blessing: And I will bless them that bless thee, and curse him that curseth thee: and in thee shall all families of the earth be blessed." [Genesis 12:2-3]

The blessing to all the families of the Earth through Abraham's line was the incarnation of the Lord Jesus Christ [John 1:14] was to the Jews first. "Unto you first God, having raised up his Son Jesus, sent him to bless you, in turning away every one of you from his iniquities" [Acts 3:26].

However, God did not stop there. The salvation of Gentiles was in His plan of redemption [Psalm 18:49], as the Lord Jesus said to the Jews: "And other sheep I have, which are not of this fold: them also I must bring, and they shall hear my voice; and there shall be one fold, and one shepherd." [John 10:16]
3 DECEMBER.part7: Christ hath redeemed us from the curse of the law, being made a curse for us: for it is written, Cursed is every one that hangeth on a tree: That the blessing of Abraham might come on the Gentiles through Jesus Christ; that we might receive the promise of the Spirit through faith. - Galatians 3:13-14

4 DECEMBER.part4: And again, Praise the Lord, all ye Gentiles; and laud him all ye people.
4 DECEMBER.part5:
The Gentiles will give praise and glory to God for His mercy is not limited to those of the house of Israel. God's mercy promised and shown to Israel is given to them too.

Paul attests this from Scriptures:
"Rejoice, O ye nations, with his people: for he will avenge the blood of his servants, and will render vengeance to his adversaries, and will be merciful unto his land, and to his people." [Deuteronomy 32:43]

"O praise the LORD, all ye nations: praise him, all ye people. For his merciful kindness is great toward us: and the truth of the LORD endureth for ever. Praise ye the LORD." [Psalm 117:1-2]

These cited from the Law and Writings (2 of the 3 sections of the Old Testament Hebrew Bible) tell us it was always in God's plan to save all nations to Himself, not only Israel.

His chosen servant to bless all nations coming through the line of Abraham, Isaac and Jacob is clear but the blessings would not be restricted to the physical blood line of Abraham. Realizing this, those outside Israel must be moved to gladness and joy. Their tongues cannot stay silent for, it is only natural that praise comes forth extolling the lovingkindness of God. By the coming of Jesus Christ, Gentiles will give honour and glory to God for His grace in including them in His covenantal love first promised to Israel.
4 DECEMBER.part7: He hath remembered his mercy and his truth toward the house of Israel: all the ends of the earth have seen the salvation of our God. - Psalm 98:3

5 DECEMBER.part4: And again, Esaias saith, There shall be a root of Jesse, and he that shall rise to reign over the Gentiles; in him shall the Gentiles trust.
5 DECEMBER.part5:
Paul cites Isaiah, from the section of the the Old Testament. Paul is establishing that there is unanimity in the Scriptures concerning God's intention for Gentiles to join the Jews in seeking Him:

"And in that day there shall be a root of Jesse, which shall stand for an ensign of the people; to it shall the Gentiles seek: and his rest shall be glorious." [Isaiah 11:10]

Jesse was the father of King David, [1 Samuel 16:1] the greatest king of the Israelite nation. The Lord Jesus is called the Root of Jesse to denote His coming from the line of David and His humble origins. After the Babylonian captivity in 586 BC, the Davidic dynasty was practically decimated. The remnant of the Israelite nation was but a stump, nothing much to look at, unimpressive, and to which no human would have placed any hope for greatness. However, God in His sovereign wisdom had other plans:

"And there shall come forth a rod out of the stem of Jesse, and a Branch shall grow out of his roots: And the spirit of the LORD shall rest upon him, the spirit of wisdom and understanding, the spirit of counsel and might, the spirit of knowledge and of the fear of the LORD" [Isaiah 11:1-2]

The Messiah from the Davidic line fulfilled God's promise [2 Samuel 7:12-16], proving Christ's humanity so that Jews and Gentiles will have saving hope, joy and confidence in Him and His kingship.
5 DECEMBER.part7: I Jesus have sent mine angel to testify unto you these things in the churches. I am the Root and the offspring of David, and the bright and morning Star. - Revelation 22:16

6 DECEMBER.part4: Now the God of hope fill you with all joy and peace in believing, that ye may abound in hope, through the power of the Holy Ghost.
6 DECEMBER.part5:
Almighty God Himself is a God of hope. He is its source and fills us with joy and peace when we believe. It is not man-made joy and peace. Our believing is not only good for the future when our Lord Jesus returns for our glorification. It is God's plan and desire that we experience joy and peace in the here and now as a result of believing in His Son, Jesus Christ.

God desires that we have exceeding and abundant hope. What actually is this hope? "Which hope we have as an anchor of the soul, both sure and stedfast, and which entereth into that within the veil". [Hebrews 6:19]

This hope is not wishful thinking but based on God's revealed character through His Word and fulfilment in Jesus Christ. He is the High Priest who died for our sins, rose from the grave, ascended up and now seated on His throne in Heaven, a secure and firm anchor for us. This is the believer's blessed hope.

Neither is hope merely cold factual head knowledge. It is experienced in our hearts as reality because of the Holy Ghost working in us. God is the source of our hope.He is also the centre and object of our hope. God gives and produces this hope in our hearts based on His work. Thus, our hope is assured by Him. We have joyful and confident expectation of eternal salvation because God has told us in His Word, appeared to us in His Son and now works in us by His Holy Spirit.
6 DECEMBER.part7: But sanctify the Lord God in your hearts: and be ready always to give an answer to every man that asketh you a reason of the hope that is in you with meekness and fear. - 1 Peter 3:15

7 DECEMBER.part4: And I myself also am persuaded of you, my brethren, that ye also are full of goodness, filled with all knowledge, able also to admonish one another.
7 DECEMBER.part5:
The apostle Paul was persuaded that the brethren in Rome was "full of goodness". Goodness in what sense? Recall that this letter began with the apostle acknowledging their faith. Romans 1:8 - "First, I thank my God through Jesus Christ for you all, that your faith is spoken of throughout the whole world." The Roman believers were faithful to the Lord. They derived their faith from knowing God's Word and practicing it in two ways. One, by good works of love and compassion to the needy, caring for those who were hurting and burdened. Two, by admonishing and instructing one another with the knowledge they had gained from God's Word, to build up the church in spiritual maturity. That is why Paul could say with confidence he was persuaded of the goodness of the believers in Rome. The same applies to us today. When we by faith in Christ build our church on the foundation of God's Word there will be fruits of righteousness and good works.

We must never think "we have arrived" especially when we see an increase in our numbers at the Lord's Day worship services. Let us not be deceived by thinking that good attendance equals spiritual blessings and congratulate ourselves for doing well. Rather we must continue to trust God and obey His Word. Only then can we be assured of being blessed by the Lord to bear much fruit through His enabling grace.
7 DECEMBER.part7: Being confident of this very thing, that he which hath begun a good work in you will perform it until the day of Jesus Christ. - Philippians 1:6

8 DECEMBER.part4: That I should be the minister of Jesus Christ to the Gentiles, ministering the gospel of God, that the offering up of the Gentiles might be acceptable, being sanctified by the Holy Ghost.
8 DECEMBER.part5:
Apostle Paul's ministry to the Gentiles (non-Jews) was in fulfillment of the Lord's message that "he is a chosen vessel unto me, to bear my name before the Gentiles, and kings, and the children of Israel" [Acts 9:15b]. Paul could testify in Ephesians 3:1 and verse 8 "For this cause I Paul, the prisoner of Jesus Christ for you Gentiles ... Unto me, who am less than the least of all saints, is this grace given, that I should preach among the Gentiles the unsearchable riches of Christ." Paul emphasized in Romans 15:15b to verse 16a that it was "because of the grace that is given to me of God .. that I should be the minister of Jesus Christ to the Gentiles".

That was what Paul did. The truth that salvation is by grace through faith in Jesus Christ was preached to the Jews first and then to the Gentiles. Paul ministered to the Gentiles by offering them to God as a priest would make an offering to God. Through the apostle giving them the Gospel, God will convict and save them by their repentance of sins and make them a people acceptable and sanctified unto Him. Today, we thank God the Gospel came to us by God's grace. Having therefore received so great a salvation, we continue to give our lives to God through our spiritual growth in sanctification. With gratitude and joy, we worship the Lord and study to obey His Word. Constrained by the love of God, we follow the example of Paul to minister to others, proclaiming the Gospel to the saving of souls. May the Lord strengthen us by His Spirit.
8 DECEMBER.part7: And other sheep I have, which are not of this fold: them also I must bring, and they shall hear my voice; and there shall be one fold, and one shepherd. - John 10:16

9 DECEMBER.part2: Fully preached the Gospel of Christ
9 DECEMBER.part4: Through mighty signs and wonders, by the power of the Spirit of God; so that from Jerusalem, and round about unto Illyricum, I have fully preached the gospel of Christ.
9 DECEMBER.part5:
Convicted of his calling by God to bring the Gospel to the Gentiles, Paul embarked on his three missionary journeys preaching the message from the Scriptures that Jesus Christ is the Messiah of the Jews and Saviour of the world [Acts 9:20,22; 18:28]. Authenticated by signs and wonders as an apostle of Jesus Christ and by the power of the Holy Spirit, Paul led many Gentiles to salvation in Christ and obedience to God's Word. Indeed, Paul could testify that "from Jerusalem, and round about unto Illyricum, I have fully preached the Gospel of Christ." Describing his ministry in geographical terms, Paul travelled from Jerusalem to Illyricum, or Dalmatia, a region northwest of Macedonia, which includes part of modern-day Croatia.

Explaining how he could travel that distance and achieve so much, Paul wrote in verse 18 - "For I will not dare to speak of any of those things which Christ hath not wrought by me, to make the Gentiles obedient, by word and deed". Paul was careful to give God the glory and not take any credit for the transformation of the Gentiles to Christ which was God's doing. He was only His instrument carrying out His will.

Similarly, God has called us to proclaim the Gospel to the ends of the world. The work of saving souls was not entrusted to angels but to men and women saved by grace. Given this high privilege, our response must be to obey and carry out the Lord's Great Commission to us in Mark 16:15 "Go ye into all the world, and preach the Gospel to every creature." God sends. We go. He accomplishes His purpose for His Glory.
9 DECEMBER.part7: For whosoever shall call upon the name of the Lord shall be saved. - Romans 10:13

10 DECEMBER.part4: Yea, so have I strived to preach the gospel, not where Christ was named, lest I should build upon another man's foundation:
10 DECEMBER.part5:
To "strive" is to "earnestly desire" or "aim for something". It can also be translated as "ambition". The apostle's only ambition was to preach and spread the Gospel to people who had never heard of Christ. He was simply following the Lord's example who told His disciples in Luke 4:43 "I must preach the kingdom of God to other cities also: for therefore am I sent." Those who have not heard the Gospel could be our family members, non-Christian friends, the younger generation who are unfamiliar with the Bible, or the inhabitants in another country who have little access to the preaching of the Gospel. How many are these unreached people in the world today? We do not know. What we do know is the need to pray for workers in the harvest fields and then go in response to our prayers.

The late Reverend Dan Ebert III brought his wife and children to Palawan (the Philippines) in the late 1950s to bring the Gospel to the natives. As a result, many believers, zealous to learn more about the Lord Jesus, were added to the church. One of the questions they asked Pastor Ebert moved him to tears. "Since Jesus came almost two thousand years ago, why did it take so long for us to hear the Gospel?" Hearing these words should move us with a renewed love for Christ and zeal to spread the Gospel to new frontiers through missions work. Just as Paul took the Gospel to those places, leaving churches with faithful believers to continue the work of faith, we must obey our Lord's leading to go wherever He sends.
10 DECEMBER.part7: And other sheep I have, which are not of this fold: them also I must bring, and they shall hear my voice; and there shall be one fold, and one shepherd. - John 10:16

11 DECEMBER.part4: ... and having a great desire these many years to come unto you; ... I will come to you: for I trust to see you in my journey, and to be brought on my way thitherward by you, if first I be somewhat filled with your company.
11 DECEMBER.part5:
Pastoral care through visitation has always been the way believers are spiritually edified and their needs met at the individual and family levels. God raised the apostle Paul to instruct believers by meeting with them where they were. This, however, could not always be done because of unforeseen hindrances such as when Paul was imprisoned for his faith. But that did not stop him from thinking and praying for the brethren in the local churches. He even planned to be with the brethren in Rome enroute to Spain when that was possible. We feel such anticipation in Paul's writing to the believers in Rome - "Making request, if by any means now at length I might have a prosperous journey by the will of God to come unto you. For I long to see you, that I may impart unto you some spiritual gift, to the end ye may be established; That is, that I may be comforted together with you by the mutual faith both of you and me" [Romans 1:10-12]. To the Philippians in chapter 1:3-4, Paul wrote "I thank my God upon every remembrance of you, Always in every prayer of mine for you all making request with joy."

The pastoral ministry in the body of Christ is a responsibility we share together. Not all of us are pastors but all of us should have a pastoral heart to reach out to others caringly. It means availing ourselves to them for mutual encouragement and strengthening of the faith. May the Lord give us wisdom, a heart like His to touch the lives of not only our brethren here but also those in the household of faith in faraway mission fields.
11 DECEMBER.part7: And he answering said, Thou shalt love the Lord thy God with all thy heart, and with all thy soul, and with all thy strength, and with all thy mind; and thy neighbour as thyself. - Luke 10:27

12 DECEMBER.part4: For it hath pleased them of Macedonia and Achaia to make a certain contribution for the poor saints which are at Jerusalem.
12 DECEMBER.part5:
The love for the believers prompted the apostle to raise funds for the poor and needy Jewish Christians in Jerusalem. These contributions were collected as Paul travelled and ministered to the churches in Macedonia and Achaia during his third missionary journey. The believers in these churches were mostly Gentiles. Paul reported that these Gentile Christians were willing to give materially to Jewish Christians. Were they rich and had plenty to spare? Not so. Paul wrote in 2 Corinthians 8:2-5 that even though they were deep in poverty, they gave willingly and joyfully beyond their means, earnestly insisting that their contributions be received as tokens of their love and fellowship in ministering to the saints. Why were they so willing to give?

The answer is found in 2 Corinthians 8:5 "And this they did, not as we hoped, but first gave their own selves to the Lord, and unto us by the will of God." They gave themselves first to the Lord, discerning that it was His will for them to help their brethren in the faith. It is God's will to use His people in local churches to minister to one another for the furtherance of the Gospel. Giving includes caring for the needy and sick, sustaining the preaching, teaching and Bible college ministries, providing for workers in the missions fields. The Macedonian giving reminds us that all can give meaningfully with joy if we will first give of ourselves to the Lord. Remember, God loves a cheerful giver.
12 DECEMBER.part7: For ye know the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ, that, though he was rich, yet for your sakes he became poor, that ye through his poverty might be rich - 2 Corinthians 8:9

13 DECEMBER.part4: It hath pleased them verily; and their debtors they are. For if the Gentiles have been made partakers of their spiritual things, their duty is also to minister unto them in carnal things.
13 DECEMBER.part5:
The Christians at Macedonia and Achaia had a love gift for their Jewish brethren in Jerusalem. It was an expression of their gratitude for it was through Israel they had been blessed spiritually. Paul reminded earlier in Romans 11 that Israel is the olive tree and we Gentiles are wild branches that have been grafted into it. We have partaken of the root and fatness of the good olive tree. These "spiritual things" as Paul puts it, include the precious Gospel and God's Word, the Bible.

Christians in affluent societies like Singapore must have the same spirit of indebtedness. Not only has God blessed us materially, He has also blessed us 'geographically' so that this country has not encountered conflicts, upheaval and serious natural disasters like droughts, earthquakes and typhoons which afflict many other parts of the world. Whenever we see our brethren in these countries in need, we must show our love and give freely to help them; because by this shall all men know that we are His disciples, if we have love one to another. [John 13:35]

The Lord has also blessed us with good education and proficiency in languages. This puts us in a privileged position to bring the precious Gospel to other countries where millions have yet to hear it. God expects and requires us to be faithful stewards. When Jesus returns, which may be soon, everyone will have to give an account. So let us be up and about serving the Lord while we are able to.
13 DECEMBER.part7: God prospers me not to raise my standard of living, but to raise my standard of giving. - Randy Alcorn

14 DECEMBER.part2: Blessing of the Gospel of Christ
14 DECEMBER.part4: And I am sure that, when I come unto you, I shall come in the fulness of the blessing of the gospel of Christ.
14 DECEMBER.part5:
Paul promised to visit the Roman brethren once he had completed the task of delivering the love gift from the Macedonian and Achaian Christians to the needy Jews in Jerusalem. He is confident that he would go to them "in the fulness of the blessing of the gospel of Christ." Some commentators think that the words "the gospel of " should be omitted, meaning his visit will be a blessing to them, that he will come with the blessing of Christ. However, leaving out mention of the Gospel does not fit well with a few points that Paul made earlier in the epistle as well as what finally took place when Paul arrived in Rome as recorded in the final chapter of the Book of Acts.

At the beginning of this epistle, Paul stated his aim for going to Rome was to "impart unto you some spiritual gift, to the end ye may be established" [Romans 1:11]. Obviously, he wanted to expound the Gospel message to them. And then in Roman 10:15, he quoted these words from the prophet Isaiah; "How beautiful are the feet of them that preach the gospel of peace, and bring glad tidings of good things!" This means that the coming of anyone who brings the Gospel fills the bosom of the anxious sinner with peace. They and their "good tidings of great joy" [Luke 2:10], will be warmly received as sent by God.

In the end, Paul did make it to Rome, albeit in chains, and spent two years "preaching the kingdom of God, and teaching those things which concern the Lord Jesus Christ" [Acts 28:31].
14 DECEMBER.part7: Are you willing to go where the Lord wants to send you "in the fulness of the blessing of the gospel of Christ"?

15 DECEMBER.part4: Now I beseech you, brethren, for the Lord Jesus Christ's sake, and for the love of the Spirit, that ye strive together with me in your prayers to God for me;
15 DECEMBER.part5:
The Apostle Paul asks his readers to join in his missionary endeavour by praying with him and for him. This collaboration between the missionary and the sending church is essential for the work of missions. John Piper explains it in this way in his book, Let the Nations Be Glad.

"The connection between prayer and missions can be seen in a passage that doesn't use warfare words but deals with the same reality, namely, John 15:16. Jesus said, "You did not choose me, but I chose you and appointed you that you should go and bear fruit and that your fruit should abide, so that whatever you ask the Father in my name, he may give it to you."

The reason the Father gives the disciples the instrument of prayer is because Jesus has given them a mission, and Jesus wants them to use the power of prayer to bear fruit. Missions is warfare, and prayer is a wartime walkie-talkie for the mission of the church as it advances against the powers of darkness and unbelief. God designed it and gave it to us for use on a mission."

It has been said that only some can go to the mission field, and many can give toward the work of missions, but all can pray. Yet it is a sad fact the majority of our church members do not attend prayer meetings on a regular basis. If you are part of this group, may today's message provoke you to join in this war; and use the weapon that God has graciously placed in your hands to strive together with fellow believers at our prayer meetings.
15 DECEMBER.part7: Prayer is always necessary for it is always profitable. But we often restrain prayer, and this is sinful. It dishonours God and hurts ourselves. - James Smith, Daily Remembrancer

16 DECEMBER.part4: I commend unto you Phebe our sister, which is a servant of the church which is at Cenchrea.
16 DECEMBER.part5:
Paul made his final visit to Corinth at the beginning of AD 57. It was during his threemonth stay there that he wrote his magnum opus - the Epistle to the Romans. This is one of the most important books of the Bible in that it has been studied and preached on by countless preachers and is loved by and has impacted the lives of millions of Christians through the ages. Yet we learn here that Paul entrusted the epistle to an unknown lady whose name is mentioned only once in the Bible. She was probably responsible for delivering it to the Roman Christians. So, it is worth our time to find out more about this mysterious lady.

From Paul's introduction we learn that Phebe, also spelt Phoebe, was a fellow believer in the church at Cenchrea. Cenchrea was one of two port cities that supported the major metropolis of Corinth in the southern tip of Greece. Paul referred to her as diakonos (Greek) which means "one who serves in ministry", or "servant" or "deacon." She was a faithful member of the church and had supported Paul in his ministry [Romans 16:2].

An important lesson that we can learn from Phebe is that we should be zealous in supporting the work of those whom God has appointed to be leaders in our church. For one, we should not be "trouble-makers" who cause them unnecessary headaches. We should be ready to carry out seemingly unimportant and lowly tasks for we never know when the Almighty God can use our labour to achieve something in His eternal plan for mankind.
16 DECEMBER.part7: ...who knoweth whether thou art come to the kingdom for such a time as this? - Esther 4:14b

17 DECEMBER.part4: That ye receive her in the Lord, as becometh saints, and that ye assist her in whatsoever business she hath need of you: for she hath been a succourer of many, and of myself also.
17 DECEMBER.part5:
Paul, brilliant, gifted and totally committed, was the greatest missionary the world has ever known. But he could not have achieved all he did by himself. He co-laboured with other faithful men like Barnabas and Silas. Together they "turned the world upside down" and brought the Gospel to the uttermost parts of the known world of their day. They preached, planted churches, and nurtured church leaders wherever they went. Still, these men faithful as they were, could not have done it without the prayers and support of ordinary Christians of the churches.

One of these ordinary Christians was Phoebe. In verse 2, Paul says "she hath been a succourer of many, and of myself also". The word "succourer" means "helper." It could also signify a patroness. That means she had probably shown great kindness in various ways to the apostle and other Christians perhaps by receiving them into her house. Now Paul asks the Romans to extend the same in assistance and hospitality to her "in the Lord", acknowledging she was a fellow servant of Christ their Lord.

This is a good reminder to us as Christians to support our leaders and help fellow Christians whom we may not know personally especially those who are from foreign lands. These could be visiting missionaries or foreign students studying at our Bible college here. This is the way God expects us to have a part in His work.
17 DECEMBER.part7: So likewise ye, when ye shall have done all those things which are commanded you, say, We are unprofitable servants: we have done that which was our duty to do. - Luke 17:10

18 DECEMBER.part4: Greet Priscilla and Aquila my helpers in Christ Jesus:
18 DECEMBER.part5:
The next two people Paul wanted the Roman Christians to greet were Priscilla and Aquila. Like Phoebe, they were his helpers. But unlike her and the others that follow, Priscilla and Aquila are named in a number of places in the Bible.

Paul first met the couple in Corinth during his second missionary journey. Aquila being a Jew had been expelled from Rome by Emperor Claudius. Paul lived and worked with them in their common occupation of tent-making while founding the Corinthian church. After a year and a half, Paul left for Ephesus and took Aquila and Priscilla with him. The couple stayed on in Ephesus when Paul left and established a church in their home [1 Corinthians 16:19]. Then an eloquent preacher named Apollos came through Ephesus. Apollos was mighty in the Scriptures, but he only knew the baptism of John. Aquila and Priscilla then told him about Jesus Christ and the coming of the Holy Spirit, thereby leading him to a deeper knowledge of Christ.

There is much we can learn from this godly couple. They set for us an example in hospitality by opening their home to Paul and using their house as a meeting place for the church [v. 5]. They were well-versed in the Scriptures seeing they were able to help Apollos gain a better understanding of God's Word and assist Paul in the teaching ministry. Another interesting point is that whenever Aquila and Priscilla are mentioned in scripture, they are always mentioned together. This suggests that they were united not only in the flesh but also in the service of their Master.
18 DECEMBER.part7: God's work done in God's way will never lack God's supply. - Hudson Taylor

19 DECEMBER.part4: Who have for my life laid down their own necks: unto whom not only I give thanks, but also all the churches of the Gentiles.
19 DECEMBER.part5:
Today, the metaphor "to put your neck on the line" means to expose oneself to some kind of risk; not necessarily physical. However, in the case of Priscilla and Aquila, it probably meant they had exposed themselves to imminent danger in order to save the life of Paul. From events described in the Book of Acts, we know there were numerous occasions when Paul was assaulted physically and even attempts on his life made. No doubt, being close associates, Priscilla and Aquila too were exposed to mortal danger. Paul was thankful, and so were his followers from the churches he had started. One is reminded by the tearful scene on the shores of Miletus when Paul bade final farewell to the elders of Ephesus. How dearly this man of God was loved by his followers.

There are many examples of brave men and women who similarly "laid down their own necks" for God's servants such as Rahab in Jericho, the Hebrew midwives of Egypt during the birth of Moses, and Esther who approached the king unsummoned. Do not think that such acts of bravery are not needed in this present generation. In many parts of the world, Christians suffer severe persecution. There are many situations where God's people will be challenged to emulate the examples of people like Priscilla and Aquila. May the Holy Spirit grant them courage to "fear not them which kill the body, but are not able to kill the soul: but rather fear him which is able to destroy both soul and body in hell." [Matthew 10:28]
19 DECEMBER.part7: And they overcame him by the blood of the Lamb, and by the word of their testimony; and they loved not their lives unto the death. - Revelation 12:11

20 DECEMBER.part4: Likewise greet the church that is in their house. Salute my wellbeloved Epaenetus, who is the firstfruits of Achaia unto Christ.
20 DECEMBER.part5:
In this passage, Apostle Paul greeted and thanked those who served the Risen Saviour with him. Paul would be aware that many of these saints went into hiding during the time he was persecuting them. They may have shared with Paul their hardship and how by God's grace they had found safe refuge. Paul himself experienced great challenges during his travels to preach the Gospel and teach God's Word in the many churches spread over Asia Minor. He endured heat, cold, and harsh conditions. He would not know if he could get food and water or a place to rest for the night. It was also not uncommon to encounter robbers on these long and deserted roads. There was zero level of comfort compared to travelling today. As such, Paul treasured and appreciated the help of those who served with him. Grateful for their partnership, Paul conveyed his salutation to each one by name though he was in Corinth when he wrote this letter.

Paul mentioned Andronicus and Junia who became Christians before Paul did. They were in prison with him for preaching the Gospel. Their testimonies and sacrifice for Christ were tremendous encouragement to Paul and God records it in the Bible to serve as encouragement for us who live in the modern era. They preached without fear in obedience to His command to "Go ye therefore, and teach all nations, baptizing them in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost" [Matthew 28:19]. We are afraid that we would be ridiculed for speaking about the Gospel; these people would go to prison for doing the same.
20 DECEMBER.part7: Only fear the LORD, and serve him in truth with all your heart: for consider how great things he hath done for you. - 1 Samuel 12:24

21 DECEMBER.part4: Salute Apelles approved in Christ. Salute them which are of Aristobulus' household.
21 DECEMBER.part5:
In continuation of Paul's salutation, he mentioned Aristobulus and his family. It is encouraging to see a whole family serving in church. There is work for every age in service. We need to teach our children to serve together with their parents and it is never too young to begin. As the human heart will naturally go astray, nurturing a young life takes effort and patience. Parenting is a great responsibility. First, our children have to be grounded in God's Word. Next, they will learn by the example we set. God records failures as well as successes for us to learn from and to be encouraged. Some did not do well like Cain, son of Adam and Eve, whom God spoke with; or the sons of Eli and Samuel though both were high priests. Timothy was a good example as he was taught well by his mother and grandmother. Here Paul mentions Aristobulus.

One common excuse is that it is challenging to bring up God-fearing children in this modern age. However, the Bible teaches about raising children. This is not a new issue. We are to bring up our children well from young [Proverbs 22:6, Ephesians 6:4]. God knew this from the time He created Adam, and He has clear instructions for us to obey. The question is whether we are obedient in following the way of God. Godly children are a good testimony for God's glory. Pray that we do not neglect this responsibility of raising faithful children.
21 DECEMBER.part7: And if it seem evil unto you to serve the LORD, choose you this day whom ye will serve; whether the gods which your fathers served that were on the other side of the flood, or the gods of the Amorites, in whose land ye dwell: but as for me and my house, we will serve the LORD. - Joshua 24:15

22 DECEMBER.part4: Salute Tryphena and Tryphosa, who labour in the Lord. Salute the beloved Persis, which laboured much in the Lord.
22 DECEMBER.part5:
The apostle also mentions those who worked hard. Remember it is God Himself we serve. We are to be faithful and sincere. We are to be persevering and diligent. We can put up a convincing show to impress the leaders of the church and others. We may also think of personal gains and benefits in our serving. People may look at the externals and be fooled by appearances but God looks into our hearts. He cannot be deceived or mocked.

Consider that Jesus died on our behalf to give us eternal life. It is impossible for us to repay whatever we do. Therefore, we serve out of gratitude for the eternal life we have received and in response to God's love for us. We do our best for Him from our heart. There is nothing too low or too small when we serve Him. Just thank God for giving us the ability to serve. "For whosoever shall give you a cup of water to drink in my name, because ye belong to Christ, verily I say unto you, he shall not lose his reward." [Mark 9:41]

Why does the Bible record individual names? These names may seem insignificant to us. We certainly do not remember many of them. But God does! Nothing is too trivial for Him. He remembers each name who acknowledges Jesus as Saviour and these are recorded in the Book of Life. Thank God that He remembers each of us by name too. The question is - Is your name written in that book?
22 DECEMBER.part7: Only fear the LORD, and serve him in truth with all your heart: for consider how great things he hath done for you. - 1 Samuel 12:24

23 DECEMBER.part4: Salute one another with an holy kiss. The churches of Christ salute you.
23 DECEMBER.part5:
Little is known about the 10 names listed in verses 14-15, but commentators offer two points of note. First, Paul was familiar with so many saints in the Roman church even though he never had the privilege to visit them. JamiesonFausset-Brown further supposes that the names listed are names of Roman Christians who actively hosted Christian missionaries and Gospel meetings. Second, commentators also point out that it was unlikely apostle Peter was in Rome during this period of time, despite what the Roman Catholic church claims, as Peter would then have been mentioned in Paul's salutations. Finally, Paul ends this section on salutations by exhorting the church to greet one another with a holy kiss. This is meant to emphasise the extent of love and care that Christians are called to show one another.

Even though Paul had never been in Rome physically up to this point in time, he was well acquainted with the Gospel work there and knew the names of many labourers probably because he often prayed for them. Similarly, we may not have the opportunity to meet some of the people mentioned in the various sections of the prayer list (for example those in the mission fields, the sick), but we become familiar with them as we pray for them and see how they are doing through updates on the prayer list.

Let us remember that Christians are called to show one another hospitality and care even if they are from different churches. This is part of being a disciple of Christ.
23 DECEMBER.part7: By this shall all men know that ye are my disciples, if ye have love one to another. - John 13:35

24 DECEMBER.part4: Now I beseech you, brethren, mark them which cause divisions and offences contrary to the doctrine which ye have learned; and avoid them.
24 DECEMBER.part5:
Paul cautions the Roman Christians to take careful notice of those within the church who cause divisions and offences. This refers to a range of different people. At one extreme were the legalists who could cause division by insisting on adherence to the law of Moses and other religious rites, when these were made unnecessary by Christ's work on the cross. At the other end were liberalists who lived in such a careless manner that they could stumble fellow believers and cause them to sin.

Such groups still exist in the church today. We may be familiar with overly enthusiastic Christian brethren who are generous in dispensing unsolicited advice on their convictions which we ought to agree with. Similarly, we also hear of Christians who enjoy the things of the world so much and actively encourage others to do so in the name of Christian liberty.

If we are honest, it is often easier to call out religious "legalists" simply because we are more likely to keep company with those "liberalists". Paul reminds us to reflect on the people we associate with. Think about the company we are drawn to in church. Are we often provoked to love and good works, or are we constantly toeing the line of sin together with our Christian friends?

Finally, are we guilty of being in one of these two groups as well? Do we stumble others with our legalistic criticisms, or do we encourage them to love the world by our worldly habits?
24 DECEMBER.part7: Thou hypocrite, first cast out the beam out of thine own eye; and then shalt thou see clearly to cast out the mote out of thy brother's eye. - Matthew 7:5

25 DECEMBER.part4: Now I beseech you, brethren, mark them which cause divisions and offences contrary to the doctrine which ye have learned; and avoid them.
25 DECEMBER.part5:
Yesterday we considered two groups of people within the local church - those who are legalistic and quick to cause division by insisting on additional laws that are extra-biblical, and those who, provoke others to worldly living and sin, in the name of Christian liberty. Often, we are poor discerners of both groups - anyone who calls us to live in a more holy manner we promptly classify as "legalistic", while we have too high a tolerance for the shenanigans of the more "liberal" church members.

The reason Paul tells the Roman Christians to take note of such people within the church is to avoid being influenced by them and falling into sin or strife with one another. Today, we are probably keen to avoid "legalistic" brethren. Naturally, we have the inclination to flee when we see a concerned elder who tells us to watch our manner of dress, our sobriety, or our testimony. Yet, this same sense of caution ought also to be present when we see the "liberal" Christian friend engaging us. How do we react when friends tell an inappropriate joke or suggest unedifying activities? Do we encourage them to continue along this wrongful path through our continued presence and (possibly) uncomfortable fellowship with him? Paul reminds us to be aware of the influence that these people have in our lives, and to avoid them lest they stumble us in our Christian walk.
25 DECEMBER.part7: Enter not into the path of the wicked, and go not in the way of evil men. - Proverbs 4:14

26 DECEMBER.part4: For your obedience is come abroad unto all men. I am glad therefore on your behalf: but yet I would have you wise unto that which is good, and simple concerning evil.
26 DECEMBER.part5:
Paul has just warned the church in Rome against false teachers who used flattery and sweet talk to deceive the hearts of the "simple". Then, in what seems like an ironic twist, Paul reminds them to be wise about what is good, and "simple" concerning evil. The word "simple" is translated from different Greek words in both verses. In verse 18, Paul cautions them not to be naive and guileless (Gk: akakos) when it comes to false teachings. They must be aware of the nature of false teachers and guard against falsehoods so that they will not be led astray. In verse 19, Paul is not talking about knowledge and discernment but how they should conduct their lives. To be wise is to make choices in life that are good in God's eyes; to be simple concerning evil is to live a life that is innocent and pure (Gk: akeraios), not mixed up with anything that is evil in God's sight. The same concept is found in what Jesus said: "Be ye therefore wise as serpents, and harmless as doves".

In today's context, how can we be wise about good and simple concerning evil? Do we define good and evil by our own standards, by the world's standard, or by God's standard? Let us be discerning, always measuring all things against the standard of God's Word, and be resolute and steadfast in shunning evil and doing only what is good and right in His eyes.
26 DECEMBER.part7: That ye may be blameless and harmless, the sons of God, without rebuke, in the midst of a crooked and perverse nation, among whom ye shine as lights in the world. - Philippians 2:15
