27 DECEMBER.part4: And the God of peace shall bruise Satan under your feet shortly. The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ be with you. Amen.
27 DECEMBER.part5:
The bruising of Satan is a reference to God's promise concerning the defeat of Satan in Genesis 3:15. Satan, in the form of a serpent, had deceived Eve into eating the fruit from the tree of the knowledge of good and evil against God's explicit prohibition. In the midst of pronouncing judgment upon the serpent, God promised that "it (the seed of the woman) shall bruise thy (the serpent's) head, and thou shalt bruise his heel" [Genesis 3:15]. In other words, the Lord Jesus Christ, who is the promised seed of the woman, though dying on the cross (bruise his heel) would crush Satan (bruise the serpent's head) by His resurrection.

Why does Paul say that Satan will be bruised under our feet? Just as we speak of salvation as a past, present, and future reality, there is a past, present, and future aspect to the defeat of Satan. Satan has been defeated by the Lord Jesus Christ through His finished work of redemption on the cross. Sin no longer has power over those who are in Christ. There is also a future aspect to Satan's defeat. Upon Christ's second coming, Satan and his angels will be totally destroyed. This is the great and final victory. Between these two victories by Christ is an ongoing victory of the saints over Satan. By the regenerating power of His Spirit, God works in and through us to crush Satan. When we choose to live by the truth of God's word, embrace what is good and right, and shun evil, Satan is bruised under our feet.
27 DECEMBER.part7: And they overcame him by the blood of the Lamb, and by the word of their testimony; and they loved not their lives unto the death. - Revelation 12:11

28 DECEMBER.part4: Timotheus my workfellow, and Lucius, and Jason, and Sosipater, my kinsmen, salute you.
28 DECEMBER.part5:
Verses 21-23 give a list of Christians who were with Paul in Corinth when he wrote this epistle. First was Timothy, Paul's young protege who co-laboured with him to build up the Gentile churches Paul had founded earlier. Next were Lucius, Jason, and Sosipater whom Paul addressed as his kinsmen. There were two with prominent backgrounds. One was Gaius, a wealthy man who hosted Paul and opened his home for the congregation at Corinth to worship. The other was Erastus, a public official. Tertius and Quartus (Latin words for "three" and "four") were probably slaves of Gaius as such names were frequently given to slaves in prominent Roman households. Tertius served as Paul's amanuensis, or secretary, writing down what Paul dictated. Paul warmly addressed Quartus as a brother. Together, they sent their greetings to the brethren in Rome as co-labourers in Christ.

From this list, we get a glimpse of Christian life and fellowship in the early church. People of different backgrounds - master and slave, Jew and Gentile, rich and poor - put aside their differences and came together in love and fellowship as one body in Christ, serving one another according to their gifts and calling, and sending their love to unknown brethren in another place. When there is love and unity in diversity, when lives have been transformed by the Gospel, the church will be a testimony to unbelievers and be effective in reaching out to those in places where the Gospel is not heard.
28 DECEMBER.part7: For as the body is one, and hath many members, and all the members of that one body, being many, are one body: so also is Christ. - 1 Corinthians 12:12

29 DECEMBER.part4: Timotheus my workfellow, and Lucius, and Jason, and Sosipater, my kinsmen, salute you.
29 DECEMBER.part5:
Although Paul did not give any details of his co-labourers in verse 21, we can make inferences about their identity through the book of Acts and Paul's other epistles. Timothy is frequently mentioned as his "son in the faith" and co-labourer in the Gospel. The identities of the next three, Lucius, Jason and Sosipater are less certain. By calling them "kinsmen", a word Paul used earlier in verse 7, it is likely they were fellow Jews rather than relatives. Sosipater could have been Sopater (a variation of the same name) of Berea mentioned in Acts 20:4. Jason could be the one who received Paul in his house in Thessalonica [Acts 17:5-9]. The name Lucius is found only one other time in the Bible in reference to a leader of the Antioch church [Acts 13:1]. There is, however, no reason to connect these two men.

All four men were likely part of the team accompanying Paul back to Jerusalem with the offering from the Gentile churches [Acts 20:4]. Each may have represented the church that sent them and were part of the next generation of leaders to take over the churches started by Paul.

God has equipped His church with faithful men to care for His church. The next generation too, has a responsibility to respond to God's call to serve as future leaders of the church so that she may continue to flourish, and the faith passed down through the generations.
29 DECEMBER.part7: And the things that thou hast heard of me among many witnesses, the same commit thou to faithful men, who shall be able to teach others also. - 2 Timothy 2:2

30 DECEMBER.part4: Now to him that is of power to stablish you according to my gospel, and the preaching of Jesus Christ, according to the revelation of the mystery, which was kept secret since the world began,
30 DECEMBER.part5:
Paul makes a significant expression of the Gospel in this benediction. He calls it 'my' Gospel. Paul is not claiming it as his Gospel, but he is stating it to be the true Gospel of Jesus Christ preached and lived out by him, servant of the Lord, "called to be an apostle, separated unto the Gospel of God" [Romans 1:1]. The Gospel tells us what God has accomplished for us through the work of Jesus Christ which means the Gospel is not human in its origin. It is God's work accomplished by God with God's own goals and objectives.

The benediction sums up that the Gospel starts and ends with Christ. Christ is revealed who was a mystery and secret when the world began. All things are centred in Him in creation and in Him in the Gospel.

This truth should be claimed as 'mine' by every Christian. The Gospel of Christ should be claimed daily as my truth, my conviction, and my life by Christians. We cannot forget that grace is the predominant attribute of God and grace is enthroned in heaven because of the accomplished work of our Lord on the cross. We seek the throne of grace boldly because of the Gospel we believe in. True doxology begins with accepting the Gospel as second to none. Charles Spurgeon said this with regards to the Gospel of Christ, "A Bible that's falling apart usually belongs to someone who isn't." "Visit many good books, but live in the Bible."

It is in the Gospel, the good news from God, that when man with a contrite heart cries out in his depravity, "How can it be?" God answers, "Yes it can be".

31 DECEMBER.part4: But now is made manifest, and by the scriptures of the prophets, according to the commandment of the everlasting God, made known to all nations for the obedience of faith:
31 DECEMBER.part5:
A recent survey conducted on the country's National Service indicated that more than 90% of the population accept the many positive outcomes and influences on society of the compulsory national service for all male citizens in Singapore. But I wonder if the participants of the survey realized that National Service is a national policy which requires utmost obedience of compliance from all male citizens here. When we read Romans 16:25-27, it is obvious a wise and everlasting God has commanded us to live our lives in obedience to His oracles found in the Bible from time past.

God was manifested as the word and had made known to all nations the Gospel of Jesus Christ. The Gospel truth demands the same acceptance as any other national policy. Christians, chosen and redeemed by God must accept and obey all things pertaining to the Bible because they are citizens of heaven. That is the obedience of faith. Without this obedience, we cannot demonstrate our faith by our works [James 2:18].

As with the nation's National Service, without obedience to this national policy, its objectives to preserve peace, promote economic development and authority of the government to govern will not be established.

The obedience of faith is our pledge of allegiance to Christ whose blood has justified us as God's elect. It is through the obedience of faith in every Christian that the Gospel of Christ shines forth to the whole world. And thus to God only wise, will be glory through Jesus Christ for ever. Amen.
